Can exercise help reduce th risk of getting a cold?

Yes! In a study of 1,002 adults published in the British Journal of Sports Medicine in 2011, people who exercised at least five times a week cut their risk of colds by nearly half compared to people who were largely sedentary. In fact, there are studies that show that exercise strengthens the immune system and helps reduce inflammation in the body.

What do you like to do to stay active?

🎥 @ziyahkarmali @ctvedmonton

Reference: Nieman DC, Henson DA, Austin MD, et al Upper respiratory tract infection is reduced in physically fit and active adults British Journal of Sports Medicine 2011;45:987-992.

Does drinking milk increase mucus production?

No! A study published in 2011 showed no increase in phlegm production.

In fact:
* Milk consumption and phlegm production among people with the common cold in a clinical study showed no increased phlegm associated with drinking milk.
* Self-reported problems with mucus were the same between two study groups — one drinking milk and another drinking soy milk.

🥛 The reasons some may note a change in the mucus after drinking milk is that milk and saliva in your create a somewhat thick liquid that can briefly coat the mouth and throat. The sensation that lingers may be mistaken for increased phlegm.

Reference: Milk consumption does not lead to mucus production or occurrence of asthma. J Am Coll Nutr. 2005 Dec;24(6 Suppl):547S-55S.

Teaming up with @halfyourplatecanada to share my clean out the fridge stir-fry! There are so many benefits to having a diet rich in fruits and vegetables and that is why I never like letting any of my produce go to waste.

Once a week I make this easy stir-fry using up any leftover veggies and pack it for my clinic lunch. Here is how to make it:

1️⃣Use any veggies you have left over in the fridge. Today, I used brussel sprouts, green beans, carrots, celery and onions. Pretty much any mixture tastes good!

2️⃣Cut up the veggies.

3️⃣Add butter and sauté onions, then add in the harder veggies first, then the remainder of the veggies.

4️⃣Add soya sauce and sweet chilli sauce. These two sauces add so much flavour to stir-fry!

5️⃣ For a heartier meal, I add in protein. Chickpeas, tofu, chicken or pretty much any type of protein works well here!

Do you like stir-fry?

My favourite homemade drink to rehydrate my kids👇

💥 Dilute apple juice! 💥 
💧 🍎 Combine equal portions of apple juice and water 

I don’t typically recommend juice on a regular basis, but when I have concerns about potential dehydration in my children, I give them dilute apple juice. It is important to dilute the apple juice because too much sugar can dehydrate more. Dilute apple juice ensures that there are still salts and minerals to help rehydrate and kids also like the taste!

In fact, a study published in 2016 (JAMA) found dilute apple juice is an effective rehydration solution for children with mild gastroenteritis (stomach bug) and mild dehydration.

Have you tried dilute apple juice before?

🛑 Please contact your care provider if you suspect your little one is dehydrated and not able to maintain their fluid intake.

🎥 @ziyahkarmali @ctvedmonton

Many women consider intrauterine device (IUD) as a form of birth control both before having a baby, and after. The IUD is effective, safe, and reversible form of birth control. 

✳️Two Main Types Of IUDs: Copper & Hormonal
Both types of IUDs are small plastic T-shaped devices that inserted into the uterus by a trained medical professional.

➡️Copper IUD
🔸How does it work? 
- Copper increases the inflammatory response inside the uterus and prevents implantation of an egg
- Copper kills sperm
- Does not impact ovulation

🔸How long can it stay in?
- 3-10 years depending on the device used

🔸 Advantage of copper IUD over hormonal IUD
- Can be used for emergency contraception if inserted within 5 days of unprotected sex
- Continued menstrual cycle while IUD in place
- No hormone side effects whatsoever
- Keep it in for longer

🔸Disadvantage of copper IUD over hormonal IUD
- Period may be heavier, longer or more painful 

➡️Hormonal IUD (Progestin IUD)
🔹How does it work? 
- Contains levonorgestrel, a progestin hormone, that thickens cervical mucus and impairs implantation of an egg
- Stops the lining of the uterus from growing as thick so an egg is less likely to implant
- Local hormone effects, very little hormone is absorbed into the bloodstream (about 10 times LESS than taking a progestin only pill)
- Ovulation rates vary depending on device used. 

🔹How long can it stay in?
- 3-5 years depending on device used

🔹Advantage of hormonal IUD over copper IUD
- Slightly more effective at preventing pregnancy
- Progestin can make your period lighter or nearly absent and can reduce cramping during your cycle
- Can be used for heavy menstrual bleeding or endometriosis

🔷Disadvantage of hormonal IUD over copper IUD
- Some women may still have hormone side effects of the very small amount of progestin hormone
- Cannot be used as emergency contraception
- Must be removed and reinserted more frequently

Thoughts/?👇

Tips on how to get your child to sleep on the plane 👇

✳️Go onto the plane awake and start bedtime routine.
We keep our kids awake until we get onto the plane and then start the bedtime routine we do at home (with the exception of brushing teeth). Read a book, snuggle and then get them to lie down on their seat with the seatbelt on.

✳️Dress them comfy and warm.
I dress the kids in the PJs they wear to bed at home. I make sure to add a comfy jacket so they stay warm on the flight. Right before I put the kids I take off their shoes for extra comfort. 

✳️Make sure to bring the stuffie they sleep with at home.
Both of the kids have stuffies they sleep with and associate with sleep.

✳️PS you may need to act as a pillow.

Any other things you do to help your little one sleep on a plane?

Tips for dressing your baby and child for winter 🥶 👇

✳️Dress For The Weather
- It is best to wear several thin layers of clothes to keep babies and children warm and dry.  The rule of thumb is to dress them in one more layer of clothing than an adult would wear in the winter.
- Hats that cover the ears should always be worn.  A lot of body heat is lost through the head so it should remain covered when outdoors.  The ears are susceptible to frostbite so its best to ensure they are always covered.
- Mittens are better than gloves because the fingers are bunched together to create warmth (and also much easier to put on!).
- Boots should be warm and waterproof.  There should be enough room for an extra pair of socks and still be able to wiggle the toes.

👶🏻Infants in a stroller or being pulled in a sled require extra bundling since they aren’t moving or playing to generate their own body heat.

✳️Safe Winter Dressing Tips
- Use a neck warmer instead of a scarf.
- Use mitten clips instead of a string to prevent choking.
- Find clothing with Velcro or snaps instead of drawstrings.  Remove drawstrings if present.
- Remove wet clothing promptly after playing.

‼️Babies and children should stay indoors if the temperature or wind chill is reported at -27°C.

‼️Babies and children are at a higher risk for cold related injuries like frostbite.

Any other tips to keep our kiddies warm?

Are tea bags better than warm compresses to treat eye infections?👇

Warm compresses can be good for our eyes! Warm compresses (placing a clean, warm, moist washcloth over your closed lids) can help treat eye conditions such as styes (red, painful lump at the edge of eyelids). But there is no evidence that using a “tea bag” is any better than a clean, warm washcloth (American Academy of Ophthalmology). On a personal note, I will say that I have used tea bags as they are affordable and fit over the eyes perfectly.

Have you ever used a tea bag for a stye?

Tips to prevent burnout this holiday season 🎄 👇

I love the holiday season but it can be stressful. I have found these tips helpful for me❤️

1️⃣Understand that it is ok to say no to activities that are stressful.
I love attending events, but also need downtime. Over the past few years, I’ve learned to say “no” when I’m feeling like there are too many activities in my schedule. This has allowed me to enjoy the events/activities that I am attending more!  2️⃣Prioritize Sleep. Sleep is so important to our health and well-being and I’ve learned to make sleep a priority for my health. I occasionally still slip up and get “addicted” to shows and go to bed too late, but way better than before!🙈.
 3️⃣Be kind to yourself and realize it’s ok to take shortcuts. I love cooking and bringing home cooked meals to friends, but that can be time consuming. On days when I feel too busy, I will bring a prepackaged gift or meal instead - I find that it is more that thought that counts!

4️⃣Find time for yourself even if it’s just 10 minutes everyday. Every morning I try to wake up 15 minutes before everyone else and have a quiet cup of coffee and plan out my day - it helps put me in the right frame of mind for the day!

❄️ Sending love to everyone over this holiday season ❤️

What is baby-led weaning?👇

Baby-led weaning (BLW) is a method in which the baby controls their solid food consumption by self-feeding.

✳️Baby-Led Weaning Versus Spoon Feeding
This is a controversial topic among parents. Some believe BLW is a better way to feed their infant, while other parents believe traditional spoon feeding is better. Proponents of BLW think it is a better way to feed as it allows the baby to experience new textures, develop their fine motor skills by picking up their food and may reduce overfeeding.  Proponents of spoon feeding think purees may be a better option due to concerns that a baby may not get enough calories or nutrients if they are self-feeding and that there may be an increased risk of choking. But what does the evidence say?

❇️I was fortunate to be able to collaborate with the Alberta College of Family Physicians and review the evidence on the impact baby-led weaning has on growth, iron intake and choking. The article was co-written with Dr. Kirkwood, Dr. Korownyk and Erin Manchuk. Our group found that transitioning infants to solid foods using a BLW approach (with parental education) results in up to 0.7kg less weight gain at 12 months than traditional spoon feeding, which is of unknown significance. There was no difference in iron intake or choking episodes between the feeding styles.

✳️What Do We Do?
In our home, we do a combination of BLW and traditional spoon feeding. During the day, George typically has spoon fed meals from our nanny or myself.  At dinnertime when we have more time George is fed with BLW. We make sure to avoid foods with higher choking risks such as grapes, and raw vegetables and make sure that the food that we give George is soft and baby fist sized strips of food.

Thoughts?👇

My favourite sweet and salty holiday snack 👇

Homemade sweet and salty popcorn 🍿 

Stovetop and air-popped popcorn is a great source of fiber and one of my favourite snacks!

🍿 It is quick and requires only 4 ingredients:
Popcorn Kernels
Butter or oil of choice 
Brown sugar
Salt

1️⃣Add kernels to hot oil (make sure oil covers the bottom)

2️⃣Place lid and listen to the popping kernels. Once the popping settles down in between pops, remove the pan from the heat.

3️⃣Add melted butter, a tablespoon of brown sugar and salt!

4️⃣Mix and enjoy!!

Can teething cause a fever?👇

Teething is a normal process of new teeth working their way through the gums. The most common symptoms of teething are: gum irritation, irritability, and increased drooling. 

Sometimes babies can have a mild increase in body temperature when teething. However, do not confuse this with a true fever, which is when the temperature is greater than 38°C. 

If a fever persists, please see your care provider to rule out other causes of fever such as ear infections or urinary tract infections.

MY TOP POSTS OF 2022❤️👇

1️⃣Should you use soaps to wash your vagina?

Avoid washing your vagina with harsh soaps or douching. There is good bacteria in our vagina called lactobacilli that keeps the vagina healthy. Washing or douching can hurt the good bacteria and increase your risk of infections such as bacterial vaginosis. 

A mild soap or cleanser can be used externally to clean the vulva. The vulva includes all of the external genitalia, including the labia majora, labia minora, glans clitoris and urethra.

2️⃣Are suspended baby jumpers like the Jolly Jumper safe?

The American Academy of Pediatrics states that “infants who spend too much time in confining equipment such as car seats, swings, bouncy seats, exersaucers, or strollers may experience delayed motor skill development.”
Health Canada also recommends that if a infant is using a suspended baby jumper that the infant is always supervised, that the manufacturer’s recommendations (age, weight, physical abilities of the baby, dimensions and strength of door frame) are followed, and that the jumper is adjusted to the babies height.

Both of my children loved jumping in their baby jumper and do so a few times a week. I will also admit that I find the jumper a bit of a sanity saver! When we use the jumper, I make sure I am close by and watching and limit the use to no more than 10 minutes at a time once per day.

3️⃣ Can you predict your baby’ gender by how you carry the pregnancy?

No! There is no evidence that the babies gender is related to the shape of the mother’s abdomen during pregnancy. 

Fetal sex can by determined ultrasound, prenatal blood test or amniocentesis.

🪒 Does shaving cause hair to grow back thicker?

Shaving is an effective and relatively cost-effective form of hair removal that removes hair temporarily just below the skins surface.

Shaving and the effects on hair colour and thickness has been studied in the medical literature. Studies have shown that shaving does NOT cause hair to grow back thicker, darker or faster.

Shaving gives the illusion of hair being thicker as when hair grows back, hair is thicker closer to the root.

What are your thoughts on shaving?👇

Does parenting come naturally?

Before I became a parent, I thought parenting would come naturally. That once my baby was put into my arms I would immediately know what to do. I didn’t.

Despite being a family physician and seeing many infants and children in my practice, I remember being so nervous when I changed my daughter’s diaper for the first time, worrying about putting her to sleep, struggling with breastfeeding and freaking out when she got her first cold.

Parenting was not intuitive for me, but I’m starting to get the hang of it a few years in! 

Did you find parenting intuitive?

January is cervical cancer awareness month ❤️

Screening for cervical cancer is done with a Pap test to identify abnormal changes in the cells of your cervix caused by viruses such as Human Papilloma Virus (HPV). Screening is important as it will allow for early detection which can prevent the abnormal cells from developing into cancer.

What to expect from your Pap test👇 

✳️A Pap test is done to look for changes in the cells of the cervix (lower part of uterus that leads to vagina).

✳️You will be provided with a drape to cover the lower half of your body.

✳️You’ll lie down on your back with your knees bent and heels rested in supports.

✳️The care provider will gently insert a speculum into the vagina to visualize the cervix and collect sample with a soft brush.

The initial movements that newborn babies make are primitive reflexes and part of normal neurological development. Reflexes are involuntary, which means they happen without trying. Most often they are present at birth and disappear within weeks or months.

✳️Moro Reflex Or “Startle Reflex”
This reflex is present at birth and disappears by 6 months. The Moro reflex occurs when your baby’s head drops position in relation to their body. It can also occur if there are sudden abrupt loud noises. An example of this occurring is when you are placing your baby into a crib or bassinet on their back and their head drops below the level of their body. The baby “startles” by extending their arms up and out with their hands open, then quickly bringing their arms together like they would hug something. Some babies give a loud cry when this happens.

✳️Palmar Grasp
A newborn infant can have a remarkably tight grip at birth thanks to the palmar grasp reflex. This reflex disappears by around 2 months when your baby starts grasping things voluntarily instead of reflexively.

A palmar grasp can be induced by stroking your baby’s palm with your finger and your baby quickly and tightly grabs on. Remember this is a reflex only and they don’t have control over their grasp until at least 2 months.

✳️Tonic Neck Response Or “Fencing Posture”
This reflex occurs when your baby is lying flat on their back. When their head turns to one side, the arm on that side will straighten and the opposite arm will bend. This gives the impression that your baby is in a “fencing posture”.  It is a subtle reflex, and you may not see it if your baby is crying or not at rest. It is most prominent around 1 month and disappears by 5-7 months.

✳️Placing And Stepping Or “Walking”  
If you hold your newborn baby under the arms while supporting their head and let their feet touch a flat surface, they will begin to put one foot in front of the other as though they are “walking”.  
It is present at birth and disappears around 2 months.

‼️See your care provider if you notice that your baby doesn’t have symmetrical reflexes or these reflexes are absent or don’t disappear when they should.

Does breast size reflect how much breastmilk you will produce?

Breast size does not correlate with how much breast milk can be produced. The size of your breasts is based upon the amount of fatty tissue that is contained within them, but it is the glandular tissue in breasts that produces the breast milk. 

People with all different breast sizes are fully capable of producing a healthy supply of breast milk for their babies.

Breast milk supply is not determined by the size or shape of your breasts but instead by how much and how often your baby feeds. If you want to produce more breast milk, try increasing the frequency of breastfeeding or pumping.  Consider utilizing the expertise of a lactation consultant.

Cervical cancer is a type of cancer that starts in the cervix (the lower part of the uterus). Screening for cervical cancer is done with a Pap test to identify abnormal changes in the cells of your cervix caused by viruses such as Human Papilloma Virus (HPV). Screening is important as it will allow for early detection which can prevent the abnormal cells from developing into cancer.

In Canada, cervical cancer screening with a pap test starts at age 25 for women who have been sexually active and should be done every 3 years until age 69.

The Canadian Task Force “Screening every three years offers about 80% to 90% protection against cervical cancer. Screening more frequently (e.g. annually) offers little additional benefit and increases the risk of detecting high-grade abnormalities that will likely regress without any treatment, yet patients will undergo additional follow-up testing and experience greater potential harms.”

Some women may benefit from more frequent screening than the average risk population and annual screening is recommended for women who are immunocompromised (ie. HIV), or previous history of cervical or vaginal cancer. If you have had a previously abnormal pap your frequency of pap testing may also be more frequent.

From the day your baby is born, doctors will keep track of weight, length, and head size. A baby’s growth is plotted on a growth curve, so health care providers can see how the baby’s growth changes over time. Like adults, babies come in all shapes and sizes. The growth charts show this by using ‘percentiles’. 

An example of a percentile is: A baby on the 50th percentile for weight is right in the middle of the normal weight range: 50% of babies their age are lighter, and 50% are heavier.

All babies grow at different rates, and ‘normal’ growth varies a lot. The important thing is that your baby continues to grow at a similar rate.

During the first week of life, your baby may drop a few ounces, but by two weeks they should be back to their birth weight.

Growth is a good indicator of general health. If a baby is not growing well, it may be a sign of a problem such a nutrition problems.

Have you heard of a growth chart?

How to manage your babies drooling 👇

Drooling can be a sign of teething, but some babies like George drool more than others. The presence of saliva frequently on on a baby’s chin, neck and chest can cause red irritation of the skin and is often called a “drool rash.

George had a drool rash on his chin when he was 2-3 months old. Fortunately it resolved within a few days once we were able to keep his chin dry from drool.

Here are the steps we followed:
* Have a soft burp cloth on hand at all times in addition to your baby wearing a bib so you can dab away the saliva right away. Make sure to pat off the drool instead of rubbing it off as that can cause skin irritation. 
* Have many bibs available as once the bib got wet we switched it out for a dry bib. 
* Apply a thin coat of petroleum jelly (Vaseline) which acts as a barrier between your baby’s skin and the drool. The petroleum jelly can also be soothing for your baby’s irritated skin. @bydrmom Beta-Glucan cream can also be used as a barrier cream!

If your baby’s rash does not improve with these steps, the rash appears cracked or weepy, or your babe appears in any discomfort, please follow-up with your doctor.

Do you need a Pap test if you have never been sexually active?👇

In Canada, based on the Canadian Task Force on Preventive Health Care (CTFPHC) screening for cervical cancer with a Pap test should begin when sexually active and age 25. Other countries screening guidelines may differ.

Cervical cancer is a type of cancer that starts in the cervix (the lower part of the uterus). Screening for cervical cancer is done with a Pap test to identify abnormal changes in the cells of your cervix caused by viruses such as Human Papilloma Virus (HPV). Screening is important as it will allow for early detection which can prevent the abnormal cells from developing into cancer.

In Canada, it is not recommended to perform Pap tests on individuals who have not been sexually active. Sexual activity can be vaginal intercourse, vaginal‐oral sex, vaginal‐digital sex or sharing of sex toys or devices. Pap tests are completed on individuals who are, or have ever been sexually actively as HPV is spread by sexual contact.

Is listening to music good for our brain?

Research has shown that listening to music can improve mood and memory. 

Music can activate almost all brain regions and neuro networks including those networks that are involved in mood and memory. 

A study published in 2022 in JAMA found that those that listened to music or made music reported a better quality of life.

A study published in 2008 in the journal brain found looked to see if listening to music regularly could help those who sustained a stroke. They found that individuals post stroke who listened to daily music had improves memory and mood compared to post stroke individuals who did not listen to music regularly.

What kind of music do you listen to?

While the risk of acquiring a toxoplasmosis infection from a cat litter box is very low, it makes sense to avoid the task if possible while pregnant.

Toxoplasmosis is an infection caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii. When cats become infected with this parasite, they shed millions of parasites through their feces for upwards of 3 weeks.

Pregnant women can also become exposed through certain foods.  Raw or undercooked meat is likely the main source of infection for pregnant women.  
Other sources include unpasteurized goat milk and raw oysters, clams or mussels.

✳️Symptoms
An infection from T. gondii usually does not have symptoms. If there are symptoms, the most common complaint is swollen lymph nodes in the neck. Other symptoms are mild and include: fever, chills, sweats, headaches, muscle pains, or sore throat.

✳️Consequences
If this infection happens for the first time during pregnancy, it can lead to birth defects, developmental problems, or even miscarriage. The risk of miscarriage is about 0.5% in pregnant women who get toxoplasmosis.  
Most newborns with toxoplasmosis do not have symptoms. However, infants may have serious problems such such as:
* Chorioretinitis – inflammation of parts of the eye and can lead to vision loss
* Hydrocephalus – abnormal build of up fluid in the brain 
* Intracranial calcifications – abnormal calcium deposits in the brain 
The changes seen in the brain can lead to developmental delays, intellectual disabilities, or seizures.

✳️Prevention
*Have someone else change the cat litter box daily. If this is not possible, wear gloves and wash your hands with soap and water afterwards. Fresh cat feces cannot transmit the parasite, but feces more than a day old can transmit T. gondii.
*Wash your hands with soap and water after exposure to soil, sand, raw meat or unwashed vegetables.
*Wear gloves when gardening or handling sand in a sandbox.
*Cook all meat thoroughly.
*Avoid drinking untreated water

👩🏻‍⚕️There are treatments available if you become infected during pregnancy.

Thoughts👇

Should you use soaps in the vagina? 🧼 

Avoid washing your vagina with harsh soaps or douching. There is good bacteria in our vagina called lactobacilli that keeps the vagina healthy. Washing or douching can hurt the good bacteria and increase your risk of infections such as bacterial vaginosis. 

A mild soap or cleanser can be used externally to clean the vulva. The vulva includes all of the external genitalia, including the labia majora, labia minora, glans clitoris and urethra.

How many wet diapers should a newborn have per day?

Six or more!

During the first few days of life a newborn should have about 3 wet diapers, but after that they should have 6 or more wet diapers per day! 

The amount your baby urinates and poops is a useful way to tell of your baby is feeding enough.

How to determine if your baby’s spit up is normal or concerning?👇

Spitting up, also known as gastroesophageal reflux (GER) is a normal process that occurs in healthy infants. In fact, ~50% of infants <3 months of age have at least one episode of spitting up per day.

✳️Why Do Babies Spit Up?
The esophagus is the tube that carries food from our mouth to our stomach. GER is a normal process where stomach contents are refluxed from the stomach into the esophagus without any symptoms or complications.

Babies can often reflux or “spit up”.  As long as they are otherwise happy and healthy with good weight gain, this is considered normal GER.

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is the process where stomach contents go into the esophagus and cause complications such as esophagitis (inflammation of the esophagus) or poor weight gain.

If you think your infant has GERD, please see your health care provider.

Georgie spit up lots, I called him my happy spitter 🙈 did your little one spit up after feeds?

Diaper rash, or diaper dermatitis, is common and often occurs in the first year of life. Most cases of rash in the diaper area is due to irritants to the skin and can often be treated easily.  

There are 4 main factors that contribute to diaper rash:
* Wet diapers
* Friction of the diaper on the skin
* Urine and feces 
* Microorganisms such as Candida albicans or Staphylococcus aureus.

Diaper rash is red skin on the area in direct contact with the diaper. Areas like the buttocks, genitals, lower stomach, and upper thighs are most common.

✳️Diaper rash usually does not occur in the skin folds unless there is a coexisting fungal infection.✳️ 

Treating diaper rash at home is as simple as ABCDE!
1️⃣A – Air
One of the easiest things to do at home is to maximize exposure of the affected skin to air. If diaper free time is not practical for your family, then frequent diaper changes.
2️⃣B – Barrier
Topical barriers are of the most important strategies for managing diaper rash at home. Pastes are the preferred product over ointments and creams. Find a barrier paste and apply it thickly (like icing on a cake!). Our favourite barrier cream is @bydrmom Beta-Glucan cream. In addition to acting as a barrier, Beta-Glucan will help heal the skin. Avoid products with fragrance or other ingredients as this can aggravate the skin. 
3️⃣C – Cleansing
The diaper area should be cleaned daily. Aggressive wiping of the diaper area should be avoided. Residual barrier paste does not need to be removed at each diaper change. Baby wipes should be fragrance free and with minimum preservatives. Another alternative is to use a damp cloth with water for cleaning the affected area.
4️⃣D – Diapers
Disposable diapers may be better at wicking moisture away from the skin. But there is no clear consensus in the literature that they are “better” than cloth diapers. Change diapers frequently, every 3 hours or more often.  
5️⃣E – Education
Avoid products with baking soda, cornstarch or talc powders, boric acid, phenol, camphor and salicylates.  

✳️ See your doctor if the rash does not improve or if you’re concerned.

Thoughts👇

What happens when you don’t get enough sleep?👇

Sleep helps us process our thoughts from the day as well as store memories, lack of sleep can lead to poor concentration, irritability and increased anxiety. Studies have also shown that our reaction time slows down with lack of sleep which an increase the risk of driving accidents. Long term sleep deprivation can increase risk of medical conditions such as obesity, diabetes, heart problems and depression.
(Sleep Foundation)

There are periods in my life when I did not get enough sleep, often because I would put sleep low on my priority list. These past two years I have made sleep a priority in my life. 

How has your sleep been?

What to do if your baby is spitting up frequently 👇

1️⃣Keeping the baby upright after feeds for 20-30 minutes.
2️⃣Avoiding overfeeding. Smaller more frequent feeds can help reduce reflux.
3️⃣Quitting smoking. Smoke exposure can make your babies reflux worse.
4️⃣Consider a 2 week trial of a milk and soy free diet. Some babies have problems digesting cow milk protein or soy proteins. For breastfed babies, the mother eliminates all cow’s milk and soy products from her diet for a two week trial to see if symptoms improve. For formula fed babies, they can be given a hypoallergenic formula that does not contain intact cow’s milk or soy protiens. This can be tried for 2 weeks to see if symptoms improve
5️⃣Try thickened feeds. Thickened formula or expressed breast milk may help reduce the frequency of reflux. Please see your health care provider before thickening feeds or changing formulas. It is thought that thickened feeds work by increasing the “stickiness” of the liquid content helping the feed be retained in the stomach.

Spitting up versus Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)👶🏻

Spitting up, also known as gastroesophageal reflux (GER) is a normal process that occurs in healthy infants. In fact, ~50% of infants <3 months of age have at least one episode of spitting up per day. 

As long as they are otherwise happy and healthy with good weight gain, this is considered normal GER.

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is the process where stomach contents go into the esophagus and cause complications such as esophagitis (inflammation of the esophagus) or poor weight gain.

🧑‍⚕️Please see your healthcare provider if your baby is having symptoms of complicated reflux (GERD) such as poor weight gain.

I can’t believe it’s been almost two years since our puppy Coco entered our lives. I was very reluctant to get a dog after treating a handful of children who received bites and scratches from dogs, but after numerous family discussions and researching safety precautions we decided to get Coco 🐶.

From following @dogmeets_baby (a wealth of information for dog training and children) and seeing my own children’s interactions with Coco, Ive learned of the many benefits of having a family dog such as:
🐶 Teaching compassion and responsibility 
🐶 Provides great opportunity for expanding vocabulary 
🐶 Comfortable and relaxed dog makes for a wonderful play partner
🐶 Watching dogs play, eat and run occupies and entertains babies and young children
🐶 Makes children happy!

For safety with our family pup we follow the Canadian Pediatric Society recommendations:

✳️ “Teach your children to treat animals gently and with respect.”
✳️“Never leave a young child alone with an animal. Accidents can happen when children tease pets or touch them in a way that makes them uncomfortable.”
✳️“Involve your child in the care of your pet. This helps children learn a sense of responsibility.”
“Make sure your pet has a quiet and comfortable place to go.”
✳️Don’t allow your pets to sleep with children.”
✳️“Don’t allow your pet to roam alone in a baby’s room”

There have been times when I’ve felt very overwhelmed during the first few months of Coco entering our family and at times even regretted the decision of getting a family pup. But as time went on and we found our groove with Coco and seeing the happiness she brings, we love having her as part of our family❤️

Learn how progressive muscle relaxation can help you sleep👇

Stress can make it difficult to fall asleep. There are relaxation techniques that can be used to help you fall asleep. I practice progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) when I have difficulty sleeping.

✳️Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) Techniques PMR techniques for sleep are a series of muscle exercises to help the body relax. If you are having trouble sleeping, try to relax one muscle at a time to help the body fall asleep easier.

✳️Relaxation Techniques For Sleep

Step 1️⃣
-Begin with the muscles in the face.  Breathe in and contract the muscles gently in face. Hold for 5 seconds.  Breathe out and release the muscles of the face to a relaxed position. 
-Repeat 5 times. Notice any changes in sensation of the muscles, without judgement. 
-Relax for 20 seconds before moving on to the next muscle group.

Step 2️⃣
-Breathe in and contract the muscles gently in neck. Hold for 5 seconds.  Breathe out and release the muscles of the neck to a relaxed position. 
-Repeat 5 times. Notice any changes in sensation of the muscles, without judgement. 
-Relax for 20 seconds before moving on to the next muscle group.

Step 3️⃣
-Repeat the relaxation techniques for sleep in step 2 with the muscles gently in arms.  Hold for 5 seconds. Breathe out and release the muscles of the arms to a relaxed position.
-Repeat 5 times. Notice any changes in sensation of the muscles, without judgement.
-Relax for 20 seconds before moving on to the next muscle group.

Step 4️⃣
-Breathe in and contract the muscles gently in legs. Hold for 5 seconds.  Breathe out and release the muscles of the legs to a relaxed position. 
-Repeat 5 times. Notice any changes in sensation of the muscles, without judgement. 
-Relax for 20 seconds before moving on to the next muscle group.

➡️Have you tried PMR for sleep before 😴?

Head lice, or pediculus humanus capitis, are tiny little pale grey bugs that are about the size of a sesame seed. They live close to the scalp, and feed on small amounts of blood.

Head lice lay their eggs (nits) close to the scalp. The nits can easily be mistaken for dandruff. It takes about 9-10 days for the eggs to hatch. The baby lice become adult lice within about 14 days – then they start laying eggs again. The cycle keeps repeating itself until they lice are treated.

✳️Signs And Symptoms
Head lice are most common in preschool and elementary aged children. The most common method of spread is from direct head-to-head contact. Head lice cannot jump or fly. There is a chance that they can spread by sharing of brushes or hats. You cannot get head lice from animals.

The most common symptom is an itchy scalp and common itchy areas are the behind the ears and at the back of the neck. Having head lice doesn’t mean your hair is dirty. Anyone can get head lice!

✳️How To Check
You need to check for both live lice and also the nits. Make sure you are in a brightly lit room and have a comb or even a magnifying glass with you.
* Part the hair and look for live lice and nits in one section at a time
* Live lice will avoid the bright lights and move quickly
* Pay close attention to behind the ears and at the back of the neck
* Nits are small yellow or whitish specks and attach themselves firmly to the hair, whereas dandruff or dirt particles do not

✳️Treatment
Check with your child’s doctor before beginning any treatment of head lice. An effective way of getting rid of head lice is with an over-the-counter treatment and the comb-out method (wetting your child’s hair and combing through with a fine-tooth comb) combined. 
In Canada, the two most common head lice treatments are: 
* permethrin 1%
* pyrethrin

Avoid home remedies like mayonnaise, petroleum jelly, olive oil – there is no evidence that these work.

✳️Tips for reducing spread of head lice
* Wash hats, pillowcases, combs, etc with hot soapy water and dry for at least 15 minutes, OR
* Store items in an airtight bag for 2 weeks
* Teach your child to avoid head-to-head contact

Questions 👇

Can getting enough sleep help prevent weight gain? 🛌 

Studies have suggested that lack of sleep and poor sleep may increase the risk of obesity. It isn’t fully understood yet as to why this occurs.  One common hypothesis about the connection between weight and sleep involves how sleep affects appetite. Appetite is controlled by neurotransmitters, chemical messengers that allow nerve cells to communicate with each other. Two important neurotransmitters, ghrelin (promotes hunger) and leptin (contributes to feeling full) are key players in managing our appetite.

In one small study, (Ann Intern Med. 2004.) men who were sleep deprived had increased ghrelin and decreased leptin compared to those who had adequate amount of sleep. This dysregulation of ghrelin and leptin may lead to increased appetite and diminished feelings of fullness in people who are sleep deprived.

Some say that if you sleep less you will have more time for physical activity and burning calories, but studies actually show either no increase or very small increases in energy expenditure with sleep deprivation. There is even a tendency towards reduced physical activity due to fatigue (Metabolism 2018). 

In addition, several studies have also indicated that sleep deprivation affects food 
preferences. Sleep-deprived individuals tend to choose foods that are high in calories and carbohydrates.

Less physical activity combined with the increased calorie intake associated with sleep deprivation increases the risk of obesity.

Thoughts?👇

Onychomycosis, or toenail fungus, is contagious. If your feet come into close contact with something that has large amounts of fungal spores, like an infected person’s socks, shoes or even a contaminated floor, their fungi can find their way into your toenails and overgrow, causing visible nail changes. People who are more prone to contracting toenail fungus include those with diabetes, circulation issues and a recent nail injury.

Wear flip flops or shower sandals when walking in warm, moist areas like gyms, locker rooms, spas, public showers, and pools. This can prevent you from catching nail fungus and athlete’s foot.

Soaking in a warm bath!

Studies have shown that soaking in warm water leads to vasodilation (relaxing of blood vessels) and increases the blood flow in our bodies. Many people will describe a subjective improved health status after soaking in a warm bath.

Learn why you can NOT determine fetal sex by how you carry or by fetal heart rate👇

🤰 Can you determine fetal sex by how you carry

No! There is no evidence that the babies gender is related to the shape of the mother’s abdomen during pregnancy. 

🤰 Can you predict your baby’s gender by fetal heart rate?

There’s no difference between fetal heart rates for boys and girls, but the rate does vary with the age of the fetus. The normal fetal heart rate typically ranges from 110 to 160 bpm for boys and girls!

Fetal sex can by determined ultrasound, prenatal blood test or amniocentesis.

Have you heard these myths?

Reference: Bracero et al. (2015) First trimester fetal heart rate as a predictor of newborn sex. J Matern Fetal Neonatal Med.

Smelly feet (bromodosis) occur when the feet get sweaty. The odour itself is made from bacteria breaking down a product in the sweat. So, any shoe that causes the feet to sweat more, like plastic shoes or other less-breathable materials are more likely to cause your feet to smell. Not wearing socks can have the same effect. 

Tips to treat and prevent smelly feet include:
🦶 Washing your feet daily with soap.
🦶 Don’t let your toenails grow too long.
🦶 Foot power or antiperspirant may be helpful.
🦶 Wear breathable or natural fabrics on your feet like cotton.
🦶 Let shoes dry out before wearing them again.

Family doctor (@lifeofdrmom) and dietitian (@getjoyfull) team up to share their favourite self-care chicken soup. 

This soup is yummy, easy and comforting. Every spoonful boasts protein, selenium, iron, zinc and vitamin C…all nutrients that help the immune system stay strong. Interestingly, a study published in 2000 in the journal CHEST found that chicken soup had anti-inflammatory properties, too! 

Rehydrate and recharge with us!

Our soup recipe is as follows:

Prep Time: 10 minutes
Cook Time: 25 minutes
Servings: 6 servings

Ingredients:
1 tbsp (15 mL) olive oil 
1 yellow onion, finely diced
3 cloves of garlic, minced
2 large carrots, diced 
3 celery stalks, diced 
3 sprigs fresh thyme leaves
1 tsp (5 mL) ground turmeric 
½ a lemon, sliced
4 cups (1 L) low-sodium chicken broth
1 cup (250 mL) kale leaves, chopped 
1 cup (250mL) cooked chicken, chopped
Salt and pepper to taste

Directions:
👩‍🍳 In a large pot, over medium-high heat, saute onion, garlic carrot and celery with oil for 2 mins.
👩‍🍳 Next, add turmeric and thyme. Cook for another minute or two. 
👩‍🍳 Add chicken broth and stir. Reduce heat to medium, cover and simmer for 15-20 mins until veggies are tender.
👩‍🍳 Uncover then add chicken, kale and lemon. Add more broth if needed. Cook for another 3-5 mins.
👩‍🍳 Season with salt and pepper to taste. Enjoy a comforting, nourishing bowl of self-care soup with crusty bread or a side of your choosing.

Why delay your baby’s first bath for 24 hours?👇

At birth babies are covered in vernix. This is a waxy white substance that acts as a natural moisturizer and may have anti-bacterial properties. 

The World Health Organization recommends delaying the first bath for 24 hours. The rationale is that babies that get baths right away may become cold and this can increase their risk of hypothermia (body temperature drops below normal). The minor stress of the bath may also increase that risk of blood sugars dripping, known as hypoglycaemia. 

Also, the first 24 hours is important time for skin-to-skin and infant-parent bonding, two important factors in breastfeeding success. One study found that by delaying bathing at least 12 hours there was an increased likelihood of breastfeeding initiation and in-hospital breastfeeding rates.

I wasn’t aware of the WHO recommendation when my children were born. Both Madi and Georgie had baths within 24 hours. Share your thoughts👇

Reference: Preer et al. (2013) Delaying the bath and in-hospital breastfeeding rates. Breastfeed Med. Dec;8(6):485-90

Learn the importance of checking blood pressure👇

I check my own blood pressure every 3-6 months and check my patients blood pressure whenever they come into my office!

High blood pressure (hypertension) is the number one risk factor for stroke and a major risk factor for heart disease, so it is very important that it is properly controlled. I check blood pressure regularly as there are often no warning signs or symptoms with high blood pressure, this is why it is often called “the silent killer.”

The Heart and Stroke Foundation of Canada does an excellent job of explaining blood pressure:

“Blood pressure is a measure of the pressure or force of blood against the walls of your blood vessels (arteries). Your blood pressure reading is based on two measures. The top number (systolic) is the measure of the pressure when your heart contracts and pushes blood through the arteries. The bottom (diastolic) number is the measure of the pressure when your heart relaxes between beats.”

It is important to treat high blood pressure as the heart has to work harder than normal to pump blood through the blood vessels. Over time, this is not good for the heart or blood vessels.

Is red wine good for your heart? 🍷 

There is a lot of talk about red wine being good for our hearts, but whether or not red wine is good for us is kinda confusing. There are some observational studies that have found associations between drinking red wine and lower rates of heart disease. The theory is that red wine contains antioxidants called resveratrol that may help prevent heart disease. However, over the years the studies on resveratrol are mixed, some studies showing benefit and some showing no benefit. Right now, it is unclear if red wine actually has heart healthy benefits. That being said, I enjoy red wine and have 1-2 glasses of red wine a week!

The truth about caffeine and pregnancy 🍫 ☕

To answer the age-old question “can I still enjoy caffeine while pregnant?” I’ve teamed up with the amazing Dr. Stephanie Liu from @lifeofdrmom 👩🏻‍⚕️💕

For pregnant mamas – especially if it’s your first time – it can be super over-whelming when it comes to figuring out what’s safe to eat/drink and what’s not. It can seem like there are a lot of “rules” – and one of the ones expecting mothers worry most about is caffeine. It definitely seems unfair – especially in that midst of that first trimester fatigue when you feel like you need that kick of caffeine the most! 😩

Caffeine can be found in a few foods and drinks – most commonly coffee and tea, and of course, chocolate! A lot of Mamas ask us whether it’s safe in pregnancy – and are happy to hear that the answer is YES! (just in moderation). 🙌

Caffeine in excess amounts has been shown to be associated with low birth weight and increased risk of premature birth or miscarriage. BUT, in small amounts it can be safe:

〰 Limit your caffeine intake to 200mg a day – that’s generally less than two cups. Caffeinated beverages will vary in their caffeine content, but to play it safe, try to just stick to one cup daily.
〰 For tea, again try to stick to one cup, or you could try a zero-caffeine herbal tea (just double check the herbal ingredients are safe – some are not recommended, especially in the first trimester)
〰 A small bar of chocolate is fine! There’s even some evidence that suggests that a small quantity of dark choc  daily during pregnancy can be beneficial for both mama and baby.

What was/is your favourite caffeinated drink or chocolate during pregnancy? Or do you have a question about how to safely enjoy it? Let us know below 💖

Being a new mom or a mom with small can come with a little (or a lot!) of anxiety. You are responsible for a very vulnerable person and much of what you are going through will be new. My friend and colleague Dr. Sarah Nunes, a psychologist had some great advice for managing anxiety in motherhood.

Understand that some anxiety is normal. Motherhood is a new endeavour with many unknowns. Alongside anxiety you may also experience mood changes (due to changing hormones and sleep deprivation), loneliness, and challenges with your partner.

Here are some things you can do to try and combat anxiety:
✳️Try ways to relax in your home:
* diaphragmatic breathing,
* meditation can help anxiety
* Do some self care – a hot relaxing bath, a massage or a short walk around your neighbourhood.
✳️Ask for help from family or friends, and find some time for yourself:
* Ask your partner to take the child out for an hour to yourself so you can de-stress.
* Ask an in-law (if possible) to come over to be with the child so you can have sometime to yourself.
* Find some down time when your child is at school or daycare to do some self care.
* Hire outside help if you can afford it.
✳️Try and pay attention to your extreme thoughts throughout the day
* Try to notice when you are getting carried away with a particular thought and ask yourself if there is evidence for the truthfulness of the thought.
* Notice the emotion that comes with the thought and label it (anger, sadness, guilt, etc).
* If you find yourself stuck in a negative thought, notice it without judgment and try gently redirecting it to a positive thought. We all have negative thoughts!
✳️Recognize when you are ruminating, or worrying excessively
* When worrying no longer generates new ideas this is called rumination.
* When this is happening, try to get busy doing something active or productive. Sitting and focusing on the rumination often makes it worse.
Accept that some times your anxiety may be worse than others, and this is normal.
Please also give yourself permission to get professional help from your doctor or a psychologist if you feel you need it.

Those first moments, when your newborn baby is placed on your chest, is an unforgettable moment. Skin-to-skin contact is not only for satisfying a parent’s desire to bond with their newborn baby, but has also been shown to have significant positive effects on a baby’s health and breastfeeding. By definition, skin-to-skin contact (or kangaroo care) is when a baby is placed on the bare chest of a parent.

✳️Benefits Of Skin-To-Skin Contact
Studies have shown that skin-to-skin contact allows for early exposure of a baby to mom’s body temperature and smell, which promotes suckling and breastfeeding. There is a statistically significant increase in the rate of babies who are able to exclusively breastfeed as a result of early skin-to-skin contact. Even among moms who don’t plan on breastfeeding, early skin-to-skin contact provides for significant benefits with regards to improved bonding between mom and baby, as well as decreased stress in baby as they adapt to life outside the uterus. Skin-to-skin contact  can even decrease the rates of sudden unexpected infant death.

These benefits are also seen in babies born via caesarian section.  Skin-to-skin contact can be done in the operating room and recovery room immediately after the baby is born.

✳️What About Dads?
Interestingly, newer studies have also shown that early skin-to-skin contact with its associated benefits can also be established between a father and child. The same warmth and tactile stimulation that a baby receives from mom during skin-to-skin can also be achieved by dad!

What are your thoughts and experiences with skin to skin contact?👇

Both of my children had cradle cap when they were newborns. Cradle cap, or seborrheic dermatitis, is a relatively common skin condition that can affect infants between the ages of 2 weeks to 12 months. It occurs most commonly within the first 3 months of life.

👶🏻What Does Cradle Cap Look Like?
Infants will have thick white or yellow greasy scales on the scalp and forehead.  The scales can be slightly reddened at the bases.  Sometimes it can also appear around the nose, ears, or skin folds. Most infants are not bothered by cradle cap, as it is a benign inflammatory skin condition that often resolves spontaneously.  Sometimes it can cause mild itchiness.

🧑‍⚕️How Do You Treat Cradle Cap?
Because cradle cap usually resolves on its own within a few weeks to a few months, the initial recommendations are very conservative.  
Start with emollients such as mineral oil, baby oil, or petroleum jelly.  Apply the emollient to the scales to help loosen them and then use a cloth or infant hairbrush to remove them.

👶🏻Hair and scalp can be washed regularly with a mild baby shampoo followed by brushing of scales to reduce flaking.  Infants generally do not require medicated creams or shampoos to treat cradle cap.  In some severe cases, physicians may prescribe antifungal creams or shampoos.  Your physician will determine if a steroid cream is required to treat your infant’s cradle cap.

❤️Fortunately, both of my children’s cradle cap resolved after a few treatments with mineral oil.

🏃‍♀️ Can exercise help prevent dementia? 

🧑‍⚕️ There are studies to suggest that exercising regularly can help prevent and delay the progression of dementia. The theory is that that exercise increases the amount of brain derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), which can help maintain our cognitive function as we age. Cognitive functioning refers to multiple mental abilities, including learning, reasoning, memory, problem solving, decision making, and attention.

🧠 BDNF levels in individuals with dementia 🧠 
There are multiple studies that have shown significantly lower levels of BDNF in individuals with dementia compared to individuals without dementia suggesting that BDNF plays a significant role in learning and memory.

Have you heard about benefits of exercise for your memory?

🎥 @ziyahkarmali @ctvedmonton

References: 
Tchounwou et al. Exercise Dosage in Reducing the Risk of Dementia Development: Mode, Duration, and Intensity—A Narrative Review. Int J Environ Res Public Health. 2021 Dec; 18(24): 13331.

Ng et Al. Decreased Serum Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) Levels in Patients with Alzheimer’s Disease (AD): A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. Int J Mol Sci. 2019 Jan; 20(2): 257.

There is a growing trend for new mothers to encapsulate and consume their placenta postpartum, called placentophagy. I did NOT consume placenta postpartum for either Madi or George.

Mammals consume their placenta after their young are born. The reason for land mammals to ingest their placentas is primarily to clean the surrounding environment to reduce predator attacks.  
Humans eating placentas after birth is a relatively new phenomena; the practice was nearly unheard of until 50 years ago. It was at that time that placentophagy was purported to reduce incidence of “baby blues” and postpartum depression, and aid in energy and lactation levels. Since then, there is now a growing trend for placental encapsulation for human consumption with the main reason to prevent postpartum depression.

There are three main reasons that women may consider eating their placentas:
* Prevent postpartum depression and improve maternal mood/energy
* Improve postpartum anemia and hemoglobin levels
* Improve lactation

❌Unfortunately, the literature completed to date has not shown any benefit in these domains.

🛑What Are The Potential Harms Of Placentophagy?
There is a case report where an infant was admitted to hospital with group B streptococcus sepsis.  The source of the bacteria was traced to the mother’s placenta capsules. The mother was group B streptococcus negative. Inadequate heating and preparation of placenta capsules may be insufficient enough to eradicate bacterial and viral infections from being transmitted to the newborn.  
Another potential concern is that the placenta can house a build up of toxic substances including heavy metals.

✳️Bottom Line
There is no scientificevidence of any benefit of consuming the placenta in the postpartum period. There is potential evidence for risk of harm.

Thoughts👇

Learn why GBS swab is recommended during pregnancy👇

It is standard of care that all pregnant women get screened for Group B Streptococcus (GBS).  The recommended time to get screened by your primary care provider is between 36 weeks and 37 weeks 6 days of gestation.  Even women who are having a planned Caesarian section will likely be screened.

✳️How Is Screening Done?
Screening for GBS is completed by the primary care provider during a routine prenatal appointment.  The lower vagina and the rectum are swabbed.  These swabs are sent to a lab to test for GBS.

✳️GBS Is A Leading Cause Of Newborn Infections
GBS colonizes up to 30% of pregnant women.  Colonization does not mean the mother is infected, it means she is carrying the bacteria and has no symptoms of infection.

These bacteria can be transferred to a baby during delivery after the onset of labor or rupture of membranes. They can also transfer when the baby passes through the birth canal.

✳️GBS Early-Onset Disease
Babies are born with very low immunity and are at a high risk for infection. GBS screening is done to prevent GBS early-onset disease (EOD) in a newborn baby. This is an infection that occurs within 7 days of the baby being born.

Most GBS EOD in newborn babies present as:
* Sepsis
* Pneumonia (lung infection) or
* Meningitis (infection in brain or spinal cord) which is more rare

✳️Preventing GBS EOD
If a pregnant woman has had a positive GBS screen, she will receive intravenous antibiotics during labor.

Most newborn babies with GBS EOD will show symptoms within 24 hours of birth.  Nurses and physicians will monitor infants closely during this time.

Parents will be counseled about the signs and symptoms of GBS EOD in their newborn baby if they are discharged home before 48 hours of life.

Gastroenteritis, commonly referred to as “gastro” or “stomach flu” is still going around and it’s important that we stay hydrated when sick.

This is my favourite homemade drink to rehydrate my kids👇

💥 Dilute apple juice! 💥 
💧 🍎 Combine equal portions of apple juice and water 

I don’t typically recommend juice on a regular basis, but when I have concerns about potential dehydration in my children, I give them dilute apple juice. It is important to dilute the apple juice because too much sugar can dehydrate more. Dilute apple juice ensures that there are still salts and minerals to help rehydrate and kids also like the taste!

In fact, a study published in 2016 (JAMA) found dilute apple juice is an effective rehydration solution for children with mild gastroenteritis (stomach bug) and mild dehydration.

Have you tried dilute apple juice before?

🛑 Please contact your care provider if you suspect your little one is dehydrated and not able to maintain their fluid intake.

Does the food you eat during pregnancy impact your child’s food preferences?

Yes! A mothers diet while pregnant can affect her child’s food preferences later in life! By 13 to 15 weeks gestation, the fetus is able to perceive smells and tastes while in the womb through the amniotic fluid. Studies have suggested that prenatal exposure to certain smells and tastes may lead to a greater acceptance and sensory recognition of these foods later in childhood. This suggests that if you eat more fruits and vegetables during your pregnancy, your little one may be more inclined to eat fruits and veggies!

Blocked tear ducts are a relatively common occurrence in newborn babies.  It is one of the most common reasons for a baby to have persistent tearing and discharge from the eyes.  One study found that up to 20% of babies will have problems with tear drainage in the first year of life.

✳️Causes Of Blocked Tear Ducts
The most common reason for a baby to have blocked tear ducts is due to a congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction.  This means that at birth, the tear duct system is incomplete, and tears do not drain properly.  Tears have nowhere to go so your baby often has watery eyes and sometimes discharge. 
The good news is that blocked tear ducts usually resolve spontaneously before 6 months of age.

✳️Symptoms
The most common symptom is persistent watery eyes. Sometimes the tearing is intermittent, worsening when in an environment that increases tearing, such as being in the wind or cold weather.  
Sometimes the lower eyelid can get irritated if your baby is rubbing their eyes often.  
The whites of the eyes should not be red.  If the eyes are reddened, this could indicate conjunctivitis instead.  
There should be no pain or discomfort with a blocked tear duct.

✳️Nasolacrimal Massage
The first line management of blocked tear ducts is nasolacrimal massage or compression.  
Instructions for performing nasolacrimal massage:
1. Wash your hands, keep your fingernails cut short
2. Using your index finger, apply moderate pressure to the corner of the lower eyelid and slide your finger downward along the nose maintaining that pressure
3. Repeat two to three times a day
This helps to unblock the tear duct and allow the tears to drain naturally.

✳️Other Management Strategies
It is important to keep the eye clean. Wash the eyelids and the face regularly with a clean facecloth.  
In some cases, blocked tear ducts can get infected and antibiotics maybe required. Signs of infection may include pain, redness, swelling or puss.  Please contact your health care provider if the blocked tear duct does not resolve, signs of infection or if you are concerned.

What are umbilical cord keepsakes and are they safe?

Umbilical cord keepsakes is the process of preserving your baby’s umbilical cord as a keepsake of your baby’s birth. The umbilical cord can be preserved in the shape of a heart and even gold plated!

🧑‍⚕️ Is it safe?
There is no published literature on the safety of umbilical cord preservation for the purpose of creating umbilical keepsake art.  
 
Umbilical cords are typically clamped and cut within 30-60 seconds after the birth of your child.  The umbilicus is an entry point of bacteria into your infants body so it is important to keep the area dry and clean. It is important to follow instructions from your health care provider to allow the umbilical cord to dry up and fall off naturally. If the umbilical stump is pulled off prematurely it can lead to bleeding in the area. 
 
🤱 What should parents know about having their umbilical cord preserved?
 
Similarly to placental encapsulation for consumption, these practices are not regulated.  As such there is a risk to improper preservation techniques and the keepsake art may harbour harmful bacteria.

Tips for a better sleep from a sleep doctor (my husband😍).

My husband (Dr Graeme Mulholland) is an Ear Nose and Throat Surgeon who did a sleep medicine fellowship at Emory University. He is currently the Director of Sleep Surgery at the University of Alberta. These are some of his favourite sleep tips:

⏰ Maintain a regular wake up time. Wake up the same time everyday, even on the weekend. Keep the wake up time within a hour.
😴 If possible avoid naps later in the day. If you do take a nap, limit it to no more than 20 minutes. Note: safety always takes priority. If you are sleep and have to drive or operating heavy machinery always favour a nap to stem sleepiness.
📺 Avoid screen-time before bed. The blue light in screens can interfere with sleep.
🛌 Limit activity in bed to sex and sleep only. Do not spend more than 20 minutes in bed if you cannot sleep (perceived time, no clock watching ;).

😴 Anything else you have found helpful for your sleep?

Is maple syrup healthy?👇
 
Compared to refined sugars such as corn syrup or white sugar, maple syrup is preferable as it has a higher concentration of minerals such as manganese and zinc. Zinc helps support our immune system, while manganese plays a crucial role in fat and carbohydrate metabolism, calcium absorption, blood sugar regulation, brain and nerve function.

Maple syrup also contains many types of antioxidants. These antioxidants may be beneficial for reducing risk of chronic diseases such as inflammatory arthritis and cardiovascular disease.

Some studies also suggest many of these antioxidants may help reduce the growth of cancer cells. However, it’s important to note that this study did not involve humans and more studies need to be done in this area.

Compared to corn syrup and brown rice syrup, maple syrup has a lower glycemic index. This means it is less likely to cause spikes in your blood sugar and raise insulin levels than refined sugars.

🧑‍⚕️So should we be eating more maple syrup?

Making maple syrup your preferred sugar when choosing to sweeten foods such as coffee, baked goods or homemade salad dressings may offer more benefit than other sugar options. However, it is important to remember we must be conscientious of the amount of added sugars we consume. Consumed in excess, sugar may be a leading cause of some of the world’s biggest health problems, including obesity, type 2 diabetes and heart disease. Maple syrup is in fact 66% sugar! Calorie for calorie, maple syrup is a very poor source of nutrients compared to whole foods like vegetables, fruits and unprocessed animal foods. Remember the best way to get minerals and antioxidants is to eat a wide variety of whole foods!

Tips from the “Blue Zones” on how to live a longer, happier and healthier life👇

Blue zones are regions in the world where people are speculated to live longer, happier and healthier lives than average. These areas are all in different parts of the world (Okinawa, Japan; Sardinia, Italy; Nicoya, Costa Rica; Ikaria, Greece, and Loma Linda, California) but they found some commonality in these regions. 

🚶‍♀️Movement throughout their day. Movement is part of their daily life - walking, growing gardens, chores around the home. 

❤️Purpose - Knowing your sense of “why I wake up in the morning”

😌Downshift - stress is inevitable in life, but in routines that help shed stress such s a few movements to remember ancestors, prayers, nap or for some, happy hour!

🥘 80% rule - stop eating when you are 80% full.

🥗 Eat lots of plants - veggies and fruits are good for us.

🤝Belonging - denomination doesn’t matter but some find benefit with attending faith based services.

👨‍👩‍👧‍👦Loved ones first - put family first, caring for our elderly, commit to life partner, invest in children with time and love.

Peanut allergies are becoming more common among children. Approximately 3.2% of children have peanut allergies. In an effort to prevent this allergy, the Canadian Paediatric Society (CPS) has recommended the introduction of peanuts and other allergenic foods around 6 months of age. Research has interestingly shown that what mothers eat during pregnancy may influence their child’s taste preferences later on.

🥜 Could maternal consumption of highly allergenic foods like peanuts reduce the incidence of peanut allergy later on?

✳️Conflicting Evidence
Early studies trying to answer this question found that mothers who consumed peanuts during pregnancy had an increased likelihood of having a child who was allergic to peanuts. However, many of the children evaluated in these studies had other allergies as well, making the study hard to interpret.  On the other hand, additional studies showed that there was likely no significant association between peanut ingestion during pregnancy and later childhood allergy. Some researchers even measured allergy-specific proteins in cord blood of women who consumed peanuts and could not find any meaningful amounts.

In 2013, the CPS released guidelines stating that pregnant women should not restrict their peanut intake in an effort to prevent allergy. Since their statement, a study followed over 10,000 mother-infant pairs and showed that infants whose mothers who had increased peanut consumption during pregnancy were actually less likely to have peanut allergies later in their childhood. This study was helpful for researchers to eliminate some bias and conflicting evidence seen in earlier research.

✳️Bottom Line
There isn’t enough evidence to make a claim that increased peanut intake while pregnant will successfully prevent childhood peanut allergies. What research tells us is that there is no need to restrict or avoid peanuts as a means of allergy prevention. If you don’t eat peanuts or have a known allergy to them, then their absence from your diet will likely not disadvantage your child’s growth or tolerance later.

Most medicines are excreted to some extent into breast milk. Very few pose any concern to an infant. The amount transferred into breast milk is usually very small and unlikely to affect your baby.

✳️What Determines How Much Medication Gets Into Breast Milk?
Medications transfer into breast milk in varying amounts depending on several factors such as:
* Maternal plasma concentration
 * Higher amounts of drug in the mother can mean higher amounts present in breast milk.
* Maternal plasma protein binding
 * Some drugs attach themselves to proteins found in the blood. The more a medication attaches to proteins in the mother’s blood, the less drug is available to transfer into breast milk.
* Size of the drug molecule
 * Larger drug molecules are less able to transfer into breast milk.
* Fat solubility
 * Some drugs dissolve into fat more readily that others.
* Maternal genetics
 * How a mother metabolizes a medication can affect how much drug gets into breast milk. 

✳️Minimizing Risk To Nursing Infants
- If a medication that the nursing mother is prescribed can be given directly to an infant for a medical condition, then that medication would be generally considered safe while breastfeeding. The amount of medication in breast milk is significantly less than what would be given if prescribed to an infant.
- If a medication is meant to be taken once a day, infant medication exposure can be minimized if the medication is taken just after nursing before the infants longest stretch of sleep (i.e. just after bedtime feeding).
- Some medications affect how much breast milk is produced. Medications that decrease breast milk supply include estrogen containing oral contraceptives, nicotine, and decongestants.  

👩🏻‍⚕️Talk To Your Pharmacist Or Doctor Before taking any over-the-counter or prescription medications.

Can hugs benefit your health?👇

Yes! 🤗 

There was a small study of 159 people published in 2021 looked to see if hugs could reduce the stress hormone cortisol. They exposed the participants to a psychological stressor and then the participant received a hug and they measured the stress hormone cortisol in their saliva. They found that hugs significantly reduced the amount of stress hormone cortisol after hugs (Comprehensive psychoneuroendocrinology 2021). To me, this study makes sense because sometimes after a tough day, I immediately feel better when I get a hug.

Sleep training your baby is a personal choice, there are many happy thriving families that didn’t sleep train. Our family decided sleep training was for us and we are happy we did it. Here are somethings to consider before sleep training:

1️⃣Do Your Research and See A Physician Before You Start Sleep-Training:
* Discuss with your child’s primary care provider to confirm that it is safe to sleep-train your child. Your doctor will want to confirm that your child does not have any medical conditions that may prevent your child from being sleep trained.  
* Research how you plan to sleep-train your child. There are many sleep-training methods out there, and choosing the best option for you is an individual choice. 
* Know that there is much information on the internet about the horrors of baby sleep training. To date there is no medical data that shows sleep-training causes attachment disorders, ADHD, depression, or anxiety. 
2️⃣Plan Out The Best Time To Start Sleep-Training
* Make sure you implement a bedtime routine nightly.  
* Do not start baby sleep training before your child is 4 months old.  But do implement a good bedtime routine before you start sleep-training.
* Figure out how much time your baby needs to sleep (the amount of sleep depends on age)
* Have a plan and mutual goals with your partner about sleep-training. 
3️⃣Safety Of Your Infant Is Always A Priority
* Make sure they are comfortable and safe in their crib before leaving them alone in their room.
4️⃣All Sleep-Training Methods Require Periodic Checks On Your Baby.  
* There is no recommended “optimal” period of time between checks. 
* The amount of time between checks is determined by your personal tolerance for your child crying and your child’s temperament. 
* When in doubt, listen to your instincts. If you are worried about your child, attend to them as you need.
5️⃣The Goal Of Sleep-Training Is To Help Your Child Fall Asleep More Independently, And Wake Up Less Throughout The Night.

Can duct tape be used to treat foot (plantar) warts?

🦶 Yes!

Plantar warts are very common in children and caused by the human papillomavirus. Although not conclusive, over the years there have been studies that suggest that duct tape may be effective for treating warts. 

Duct tape may not be effective in treating all plantar warts, but it is safe and well tolerated and parents can try at home for their children. 

For duct tape therapy, the Canadian Family Physician Journal recommends “apply a small piece of duct tape directly on the wart once every 4 to 7 days; then remove the tape, clean the area with soap and water, and remove the dead skin using an emery board. Apply another piece of tape 12 hours later. Repeat this cycle for 4 to 6 weeks.”

Have you heard of duct tape therapy for warts?

How much water should we drink per day? 💦 

The National Academy of Medicine suggests an about 13 cups of daily fluids for healthy men and 9 cups for healthy women. Higher amounts may be needed for hot weather or if your doing more exercise. It’s important to note that this amount is not a daily target, but a general guide as each person’s exact fluid needs vary, even day-to-day. One tip that I find helpful to assess hydration is checking the colour of your urine as our urine colour can reflect our hydration status (Frontiers Nutrition 2020). If your urine is dark, you are likely dehydrated and should increase your intake of fluids. If your urine is completely clear it indicates that you are fully hydrated and drinking more water than required. The ideal colour of urine is a pale yellow!

Ear pain is a common problem that can occur in children during air travel as a result of pressure changes during flying. Pressure changes inside the ear during takeoff and landing can cause discomfort or even pain. Here are some tips we found helpful to prevent and treat ear pain for our children during flights:

💦 Drink fluids: Drinking fluids promotes swallowing which helps keep the eustachian tubes open and allows for ear pressure equalization.
🍬 Chewing gum or suck on hard candy: For older children chewing gum or sucking on candy can help equalize the pressure in the ear.
🍼Sucking: For baby’s, offer them a bottle or pacifier to suck on during takeoff and landing. Breastfeeding will also work well.
💊 Ibuprofen or acetaminophen: if your child has experienced ear pain previously, consider giving them acetaminophen or ibuprofen 30 minutes prior to takeoffs or landings. 
🧑‍⚕️Breathing exercises: older children can practice this exercise during takeoff and landing. Breath in slowly and then gently pitch the tip of the nose and gently exhale through the nose while keeping the mouth closed. Do this as many times as needed.

Have you tried these tips before?👇

Sleep is important for our overall health, it allows our body and mind to recharge.

The amount of sleep that we need changes throughout our lifetime. My husband (Dr Graeme Mulholland) is an Ear Nose and Throat Surgeon is a sleep medicine specialist and the Director of Sleep Surgery at the University of Alberta. He highlights the recommended amount of sleep that we need as we age:

* Newborn Sleep (0-3 months): 14-17 hours each day
* Infants Sleep (4-11 months): 12-15 hours each day
* Toddlers Sleep (1-2 years): 11-14 hours each day
* Preschoolers Sleep (3-5): 10-13 hours each day
* School age children Sleep (6-13): 9-11 hours each day
* Teenagers Sleep (14-17): 8-10 hours each day
* Younger adults Sleep (18-25): 7-9 hours each day
* Adults Sleep (26-64): 7-9 hours each day
* Older adults (65+): 7-8 hours each day

👶🏻👧🏻👦🏻Children from 0 – 4 years old will often have sleep that is divided between night time sleep, and day time napping.

There are nights I stay up later than I would like, but overall I’ve been better at having a consistent bedtime. Have you been getting enough sleep?

Tummy time can start from day 1 (American Academy of Pediatrics). 

Tummy time describes the times when you place your baby on his or her stomach while your baby is awake and someone is watching. It is important because:
✳️Helps prevent flat spots on the back of your baby’s head.
✳️Helps the muscles of the neck and shoulder develop so your baby can start to sit up, crawl, and walk.

Tummy time is recommended 2-3 times per day starting for short periods of time (3-5 minutes) and then slowly increasing the time interval.

Should you worry if your baby isn’t crawling? 

The CDC recently removed crawling as a developmental milestone after years of acknowledging it as one. Here’s what we know—Do some babies skip crawling and have no issues down the line? You bet! 

There are a few things to consider with this change. Not all babies need to crawl to have healthy development, but we also know skipping crawling happens more frequently in children with another diagnosis and we know the gross motor benefits of hands and knees crawling. The important part to remember here is while these can be correlated, it isn’t causation. Meaning, if your child skipped crawling, it doesn’t guarantee an issue.

When a little one crawls on hands and knees they are working on a host of gross motor skills including:
-Bilateral Coordination/Reciprocal Movement 
-Lower & Upper Extremity Weight Bearing 
-Hand/Eye Coordination 
-Shoulder & Hip Strengthening 
-Core Strengthening & Control 
-Body Awareness
-Upper & Lower Extremity Motor Planning 
-Sensory Input At Open Palms

So we know the benefits of crawling are there and promoting the tummy time down for crawling is beneficial, but is development variable? Absolutely. Does it mean a sure fire issue if your baby isn’t crawling? No, definitely not.

It’s never too late to use hands & knees crawling to promote the gross motor benefits noted above. If you child is older they can still cue in some of those benefits creatively. 
-Crawling Tunnel
-Animal Walks 
-Crawling Obstacle course items: crawling under, through tunnels, etc. 

So bottom line: if your baby skipped crawling and has normal development in other areas, you likely don’t need to worry!

What is a common cause of heel pain (plantar fasciitis)?

One of the most common causes of heel pain is a problem called “plantar fasciitis.” Plantar fasciitis is when a part of the foot called the plantar fascia gets irritated. The plantar fascia is a tough band of tissue that connects the heel bone to the toes. Plantar fasciitis can occur from wearing poor footwear, running, jumping or standing or walking for long periods of time.

The most common symptom is pain at the heel of the foot. The pain is often worst when you first get out of bed in the morning. It can also be bad when you get up after being seated for some time.

Plantar fasciitis can often be diagnosed by a care provider with a history and physical exam of your feet to locate the painful areas.

I often get plantar fasciitis after very long walks or with wearing heels🙈.
