🤰 Pregnancy and sleep

I found sleep very challenging when I was pregnant. Sleep problems during pregnancy are common, in fact, at least 50 percent of pregnant moms experience insomnia. There are many factors that lead to difficulty sleeping during pregnancy such as fluctuating hormone levels, general physical discomfort, nausea, increased urination and leg cramps to name a few. As time wears on, expectant mothers may also experience back pain and have trouble finding a comfortable position to accommodate the growing baby bump, especially when the baby starts to kick at night. There are also some sleep disorders that can arise during pregnancy such as obstructive sleep apnea, restless leg syndrome and gastroesophageal reflux disorder. 

😴 How to improve sleep during pregnancy?

Starting with good sleep hygiene such as keeping a consistent wake up time, and a relaxing bedtime routine.

Next, is finding a comfortable sleep environment such as a cool, dark, quiet room. Finding a comfortable sleep position, I recommend the lying on your left side with your legs slightly curled and I liked having a pregnancy pillow to support my belly and to put in between my legs.

If you are experiencing heartburn or indigestion, try eating smaller and more frequent meals throughout the day and avoid heavy or spicy foods close to bedtime. Getting exercise during the day can also help improve your sleep. If sleep disturbances persist or significantly impact your daily functioning, see your healthcare provider.

Common warts (verruca vulgaris) are very common in children and caused by the human papillomavirus. Although not conclusive, over the years there have been studies that suggest that duct tape may be effective for treating warts. 

Duct tape may not be effective in treating all plantar warts, but it is safe and well tolerated and parents can try at home for their children. 

For duct tape therapy, the Canadian Family Physician Journal recommends “apply a small piece of duct tape directly on the wart once every 4 to 7 days; then remove the tape, clean the area with soap and water, and remove the dead skin using an emery board. Apply another piece of tape 12 hours later. Repeat this cycle for 4 to 6 weeks.”

When to worry about your child’s cold symptoms?👇

Most colds and flus can be managed at home for children without pre-existing medical conditions. Most children will recover with getting enough rest, staying home when they’re unwell, drinking lots of fluids and then using pain and fever medications as needed. However if your child is experiencing any of the following, please take your child in to see the doctor!

🤒 If your child is refusing to take fluids and is not peeing frequently you should see your doctor.
🤒If your child is having difficulty breathing, working hard to breathe or breathing rapidly.
🤒 Behavioral changes including lethargy.
🤒Persistent fever, anything beyond 3 days see assessment (note: babies under 3 months of age with a fever should be assessed)
🤒Parents know their children well and if you are worried please bring your child in.

Does the food you eat during pregnancy impact your child’s food preferences?

Yes! A mothers diet while pregnant can affect her child’s food preferences later in life! By 13 to 15 weeks gestation, the fetus is able to perceive smells and tastes while in the womb through the amniotic fluid. Studies have suggested that prenatal exposure to certain smells and tastes may lead to a greater acceptance and sensory recognition of these foods later in childhood. This suggests that if you eat more fruits and vegetables during your pregnancy, your little one may be more inclined to eat fruits and veggies!

I think these three tips can help improve health and happiness.

⭐️Point 1: Move your body well. Movement can come through walking, gardening and even doing chores throughout the house. Studies have shown that being physically active is beneficial to both physical and mental health.

⭐️ Point 2: Feed your body well. Food is how we nourish our bodies. Studies have shown that a diet rich in fruits and vegetables can lower blood pressure, reduce risk of heart disease and stroke, reduce risk of some cancers and improve blood sugars.

⭐️ Point 3: Rest your body well. One of my favourite ways to rest my body is ensuring I get an adequate amount of sleep. During sleep the body performs a number of repairing and maintaining processes that affect nearly every part of the body. Sleep is important for our mood, heart health and immune system. Studies have shown that people who don’t get enough sleep are at higher risk of experiencing mental distress and that developing a consistent sleep routine can improve mood and reduce anxiety. Adequate sleep also promotes cardiac health. During sleep, heart rate slows down, and blood pressure decreases. This means that during sleep, the heart and vascular system are able to rest. That is why lack of sleep is a risk factor for heart problems. Sleep is also important for growth and the immune system. During sleep, the body produces growth hormones necessary for development in children and adolescents. These growth hormones also repair tissues and cells in people of all ages. The body also produces cytokines during sleep, which support the immune system in fighting infections.

Anti-aging tips from a family doctor (@lifeofdrmom ) and a dermatologist (@russwong.md )👇

⭐️ Wash your face when you wake up and when you go to sleep.

⭐️ Irritating your skin accelerates skin aging. Gentle washing helps to remove pollution, makeup, and other substances without irritating your skin.

Daily use of a vitamin C formulation can help improve the appearance of fine and coarse wrinkles of the face and neck, as well as improved overall skin texture and appearance. Retinoids help your skin make more collagen, they soften wrinkles and fine lines.

The accuracy of home pregnancy tests👇

When used correctly, home pregnancy tests are generally quite accurate. The accuracy of a home pregnancy test can vary depending on several factors, including the sensitivity of the test, what time of day you take the test and user error.
✅Sensitivity of the Test: Home pregnancy tests are designed to detect the hormone human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) in urine. hCG levels rise during pregnancy. In general, most at home brands should be reliable, but some tests may detect lower levels of hCG earlier in pregnancy, while others may require a higher level of hCG to produce a positive result.
✅Timing: The accuracy of a home pregnancy test also depends on when you take the test. It is best to wait until after your missed period to get the most reliable results. Testing too early, especially before your period is due, can result in a false negative because the hCG levels may not be high enough to be detected.
✅Time of day: Urine pregnancy tests should be taken first thing in the morning, this is the time of day when your HCG levels will be the most concentrated and easily detected.
✅User Error: Misreading the results, misinterpreting faint lines, or not waiting long enough for the results to develop can all impact the outcome.

In general, when taken correctly after a missed period, home pregnancy tests are considered highly accurate. If you get a positive result, check in with your healthcare provider. Your healthcare provider may order an ultrasound to confirm the pregnancy dates. If you get a negative result, it’s possible that you tested too early. You can wait a few days and retest, or check in with healthcare provider.

Despite knowing the info behind home pregnancy tests, when I did my first home pregnancy test with my daughter and saw the positive result I ended up doing another 3 to confirm 🙈.

Yes, there are studies that suggest that honey can reduce cough severity and frequency in children. In fact, in a review article published in Canadian Family Physician in 2014 they state honey can be given as a single dose of 2.5ML before bedtime for children over 1 year of age with cough. 

❌Note: Honey should not be given to children under 1 year of age due to risk of infant botulism.

Parenting topics that cause conflict between me and my mom (grandma)👇

📺 Screen time.
I grew up being able to watch as much TV as I wanted. I try to limit screen time for my kids to 1-2 hours per day. My mom is much more permissive than I on screen time and allows my kids to regulate their own screen time which can sometimes be A LOT 🙈. My mom and I have resolved our screen time battle by meeting in the middle. The kids are allowed to have more screen time at their grandparents house than at home and my mom agreed to a maximum of 3 hours per day.

😴 Sleep routines.
As a child I was allowed to stay up late on weekends. For my kids I try to keep their bedtime similar every night regardless of whether it is a weekday or weekend. I find that even if my kids stay up late they will often still wake up early. We used to get into conflict because my mom would let the kids stay up late but with time we both saw that the late nights resulted in the kids getting extremely wild! My mom and I are now both aligned for the kids to have early and consistent bedtime 🥰.

✍️Discipline.
My mom and I both have a different approach to discipline. We are still working on finding a resolution to this topic 😱🤪🤨.

There is a growing trend for new mothers to encapsulate and consume their placenta postpartum, called placentophagy. I did NOT consume placenta postpartum for either Madi or George.

Mammals consume their placenta after their young are born. The reason for land mammals to ingest their placentas is primarily to clean the surrounding environment to reduce predator attacks.

Humans eating placentas after birth is a relatively new phenomena; the practice was nearly unheard of until 50 years ago. It was at that time that placentophagy was purported to reduce incidence of “baby blues” and postpartum depression, and aid in energy and lactation levels. Since then, there is now a growing trend for placental encapsulation for human consumption with the main reason to prevent postpartum depression.

There are three main reasons that women may consider eating their placentas:
* Prevent postpartum depression and improve maternal mood/energy
* Improve postpartum anemia and hemoglobin levels
* Improve lactation

❌Unfortunately, the literature completed to date has not shown any benefit in these domains.

🛑What Are The Potential Harms Of Placentophagy?
There is a case report where an infant was admitted to hospital with group B streptococcus sepsis.  The source of the bacteria was traced to the mother’s placenta capsules. The mother was group B streptococcus negative. Inadequate heating and preparation of placenta capsules may be insufficient enough to eradicate bacterial and viral infections from being transmitted to the newborn.  
Another potential concern is that the placenta can house a build up of toxic substances including heavy metals.

✳️Bottom Line
There is no scientificevidence of any benefit of consuming the placenta in the postpartum period. There is potential evidence for risk of harm.

Thoughts👇

Cooking with a cast iron pan can increase the amount of iron in food👇

Cooking with a cast iron pan can increase the iron content in food, especially foods that are acidic or high in moisture!

When you cook in a cast iron pan, small amounts of iron from the pan can be transferred into the food during the cooking process. Acidic foods like tomatoes can increase the transfer of iron from the pan into the foods.

The amount of iron transferred to the food from cast iron varies depending on factors such as the cooking time, type of food that is being cooked and the cast iron pan itself. For example, a well seasoned pan will prevent food from sticking and enhances the iron transfer to food. In general, the longer the food is cooked in the pan, the more iron it absorbs.

It’s important to note that the increase in iron content is usually not significant enough to meet the recommended daily intake of iron on its own. However, it can contribute a small amount to your overall iron intake, which is beneficial to those who struggle getting adequate amounts of iron in their diet.

Did you know cooking with a cast iron pot can increase iron content in food?

🍭 Does candy (sugar) make kids hyper?
 
Interestingly, scientific research does not consistently support that sugar consumption causes children’s hyperactivity. I was surprised by this because I have seen my kids become hyper after having candy at birthday parties. So I reviewed evidence and I’ll share one of the studies I reviewed. In the study, the put parents into two groups, one group was told their kids had a sugary soda while the other group was told that their kids had a sugar free soda. They had the parents rate their child’s behaviour.  Parents who were told their child received sugar loaded soda rated their children’s behaviour as significantly worse and more active than those who were told their children drank sugar free soda. The catch was that all the kids in the study received sugar free soda.
 
Reference: Hoover DW, Milich R. Effects of sugar ingestion expectancies on mother-child interactions. J Abnorm Child Psychol. 1994 Aug;22(4):501-15. doi: 10.1007/BF02168088. PMID: 7963081. 
 
🙋‍♀️ Why kids may seem more hyper after consuming sugar?
The perceived increase in hyperactivity is likely due to many factors such as the excitement of having candy on special occasions (e.g., birthday parties or dressing up for halloween), the social environment as children are often among friends when having candy, and the expectation that sugary foods may lead to hyperactivity, I know I have said to my kids, “all this sugar is going to make you crazy”

🛑 Even though sugar itself may not make your child hyper, it affect your child’s health and future. It is important to limit consumption of sugary foods as high consumption of sugary processed foods can increase the risk of serious medical conditions like obesity, diabetes, and high blood pressure.

Family doctor (@lifeofdrmom) and her husband ENT surgeon (@graememulhollandmd) team up to share common causes of nosebleeds👇

Nosebleeds, also known as epistaxis, is a common problem and can happen for various reasons. The most common causes of nosebleeds include:

👃🏾 Dry air: Dry or low-humidity environments can dry out the nasal membranes, making them more susceptible to bleeding. This is especially common during the winter months when indoor heating systems can reduce humidity.

👃🏾 Nose picking: Frequent or aggressive nose picking can damage the delicate blood vessels inside the nose, leading to bleeding.

👃🏾 Nasal trauma Accidental injury to the nose, such as a blow to the face, can cause epistaxis.

👃🏾 Medications: Certain medications, especially those that thin the blood (anticoagulants) or have a drying effect on mucous membranes, may increase the risk of nosebleeds.

🧑‍⚕️ To treat a nosebleed, you can follow these steps:

✅Stay calm: Nosebleeds can be alarming but usually aren’t serious. 
✅Pinch the nostrils: More than 90% of nose bleeds come from the front part of the nose called the nasal septum. Use your thumb and forefinger to pinch your nostrils (squishy part of the nose) together with firm but not painful pressure. Important: Hold this position for 10-15 minutes without letting go. Breathe through your mouth during this time.
✅Keep your head higher than your heart: this reduces blood flow to the site of the nose bleed.
✅Lean forward slightly: Tilting your head slightly forward will help prevent blood from flowing down the back of your throat.
✅Avoid blowing your nose: Refrain from blowing your nose or putting tissues into your nostrils immediately after a nosebleed, as this can disrupt the clotting process.
✅Apply petroleum jelly or water-soluble gel (Secaris) to both nostrils: there is good evidence this will prevent further nose bleeds.
✅Moisturize your nose: After the bleeding stops, you can apply a saline nasal spray or use a humidifier to keep your nasal passages moist and prevent further bleeding.

Please see your healthcare provider if you are experience frequent nosebleeds or if the bleeding persists.

Thoughts/?👇

How to manage your babies drooling 👇

Drooling can be a sign of teething, but some babies like George drool more than others. The presence of saliva frequently on on a baby’s chin, neck and chest can cause red irritation of the skin and is often called a “drool rash.

George had a drool rash on his chin when he was 2-3 months old. Fortunately it resolved within a few days once we were able to keep his chin dry from drool.

Here are the steps we followed:
* Have a soft burp cloth on hand at all times in addition to your baby wearing a bib so you can dab away the saliva right away. Make sure to pat off the drool instead of rubbing it off as that can cause skin irritation. 
* Have many bibs available as once the bib got wet we switched it out for a dry bib. 
* Apply a thin coat of barrier cream like petroleum jelly (Vaseline) or @bydrmom Beta cream which acts as a barrier between your baby’s skin and the drool. The Beta-glucan in the @bydrmom Beta cream can help heal and hydrate the irritated skin.

If your baby’s rash does not improve with these steps, the rash appears cracked or weepy, or your babe appears in any discomfort, please follow-up with your doctor.

Should you treat your child’s fever?

🌡️ Not necessarily! Not all fevers need to be treated. If a child is playing, eating and drinking well and doesn’t look like they are in discomfort you don’t need to treat the fever with Ibuprofen (Advil) or Acetaminophen (Tylenol). When I talk to my patients I say, treat your child, not the number on the thermometer! How high the temperature is does not corelate with how sick your child is.  How your child is acting while having a fever is a better tell of how sick they are.

There are times when fever should be assessed 
🤒 Baby under 3 months of age.
🤒 Fever for more than 3 days.
🤒 Fever in a child with an underlying medical condition.

Crooked teeth can be caused by a variety of factors, including:
✳️Malocclusion: Malocclusion is caused by a difference between the size of the upper and lower jaws or between the jaw and tooth size. This can cause crooked teeth or gaps.
✳️Genetics: Another cause of crooked teeth can be inherited from parents. If a person’s parents have crooked teeth or a misaligned bite, there is a higher chance that they will also have crooked teeth/misaligned bite.
✳️Thumb sucking or pacifier use: Prolonged thumb sucking or pacifier use can put pressure on the teeth and jaw, leading to misalignment.
✳️Tongue thrusting: Habitual tongue thrusting, where the tongue pushes against the front teeth while swallowing or speaking, can cause the teeth to shift out of alignment.
✳️Early loss of baby teeth: If baby teeth are lost prematurely due to decay or trauma, it can loss of space for erupting permanent teeth, leading to crookedness.
✳️Mouth breathing: Chronic mouth breathing can affect the development of the jaw and facial structure, potentially leading to narrow upper jaw and crooked teeth.
✳️Trauma or injury: Accidents or injuries to the face or mouth can cause permanent teeth to be delayed in eruption with potential loss of space and crooked teeth.

It is important to note that these factors can vary from person to person, and often, multiple factors can contribute to crooked teeth. Consulting with a dentist or orthodontist can help determine the specific cause and provide appropriate treatment options.

What to do if your child has nightmares?👇

Nightmares are scary or upsetting dreams that wake a person up and make it difficult for them to go back to sleep. Children might wake up crying and feeling afraid to sleep. 
Nightmares are different than night terrors. Night terrors are a partial waking from sleep with behaviors such as kicking, screaming, and possibly even jumping out of bed. Children do not remember night terrors the next morning.

👻 How To Help A Child With Nightmares?
I reviewed resources from Stanford University and the Canadian Paediatric Society on ways we can help our child with nightmares: 
* Comfort, reassure and cuddle your child 
* Talk about the bad dreams in the morning and ask them about what scared them so you can understand the situation better
* Avoid watching frightening movies or TV shows
* Leave the door open and do not close the door on a fearful child
* Provide a stuffed animal or toy for comfort
* During the bedtime routine, talk about happy or fun things
* Help your child work through fears by reading books, making up stories or even drawing the monster that scares them 

Two years ago for an entire week, Madi had nightmares. Fortunately, with the steps above they resolved ❤️.

Learn why GBS swab is recommended during pregnancy👇
It is standard of care that all pregnant women get screened for Group B Streptococcus (GBS).  The recommended time to get screened by your primary care provider is between 36 weeks and 37 weeks 6 days of gestation.  Even women who are having a planned Caesarian section will likely be screened.
✳️How Is Screening Done?
Screening for GBS is completed by the primary care provider during a routine prenatal appointment.  The lower vagina and the rectum are swabbed.  These swabs are sent to a lab to test for GBS.
✳️GBS Is A Leading Cause Of Newborn Infections
GBS colonizes up to 30% of pregnant women.  Colonization does not mean the mother is infected, it means she is carrying the bacteria and has no symptoms of infection.
These bacteria can be transferred to a baby during delivery after the onset of labor or rupture of membranes. They can also transfer when the baby passes through the birth canal.
✳️GBS Early-Onset Disease
Babies are born with very low immunity and are at a high risk for infection. GBS screening is done to prevent GBS early-onset disease (EOD) in a newborn baby. This is an infection that occurs within 7 days of the baby being born.
Most GBS EOD in newborn babies present as:
* Sepsis
* Pneumonia (lung infection) or
* Meningitis (infection in brain or spinal cord) which is more rare
✳️Preventing GBS EOD
If a pregnant woman has had a positive GBS screen, she will receive intravenous antibiotics during labor.
Most newborn babies with GBS EOD will show symptoms within 24 hours of birth.  Nurses and physicians will monitor infants closely during this time.
Parents will be counseled about the signs and symptoms of GBS EOD in their newborn baby if they are discharged home before 48 hours of life.

It can be very distressing when your child has a cold. Cough, congestion, and sore throats can affect their sleep, their eating habits, and they may be more irritable. Unfortunately, there is no cure for the common cold. Parents often bring their babies and young children into my office asking what they can do to alleviate their baby or child’s cold symptoms.

Many of the products available on the shelves of pharmacies are not suitable for young children or babies for the treatment of the common cold. In fact, Health Canada requires that all cough and cold products are labeled that they should not be used in children under 6 years old. .
🛑What You Should Avoid And Why:

❌Antihistamines (eg. Diphenhydramine)
* No benefit in the treatment of the common cold
* Many potential side effects including sedation, paradoxical excitability, slowed breathing, hallucinations

❌Antitussives/Cough Medicine (eg. dextromethorphan)
* Lack of proven benefit in children
* Risk for overdose due to lack of evidence in children causing slowed breathing or behavioural disturbances

❌Expectorants (eg. Guaifenesin)
* No benefit in the treatment of cough in children

❌Decongestants (eg. Pseudorphedrine)
* Benefits are unproven in children
* Potential for harm due to overdose and enhanced side effects seen in children (increased heart rate, irritability, sleeplessness, seizures)

❌Vapor Rubs (eg. Menthol)
* Menthol does not improve nasal airflow in studies
* Potential side effects include burning sensations of the skin, nose and eyes, rash/redness of the skin where it is applied.

✳️Always ask your doctor or pharmacist which medicines or treatments are safe and effective for treating your child’s cold🤒

✳️How has this cold and flu season been for you?

Home pregnancy tests are an amazing tool - we’ve been using them since around the 70s, and they have high levels of accuracy (although a blood test will always be the gold standard).

Pregnancy tests work by detecting a hormone called Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). This hormone rapidly starts increasing after the fertilized egg implants itself in the uterus ~6-12 days after conception.

So, when deciding whether to take a home pregnancy test, patience is very much your ally. Taking a test too early may lead to false negatives due to hCG levels not being high enough to detect. Instead, waiting until the first day of your missed period increases the accuracy significantly as hCG would have had much more time to rise to a level high enough to detect.

Apart from a missed period, you might consider taking a home pregnancy test because:
〰️Your breasts feel tender and sore or seem to be fuller
〰️You’re urinating more frequently
〰️You have a headache that seems out of the blue
〰️You feel like you’re on an emotional roller coaster
〰️You’re experiencing cravings/aversions
〰️You missed a dose of birth control/your birth control failed
〰️You feel nauseous/sick
〰️You just have a hunch

✨Remember✨ whatever the result, your next step should be a consult with your healthcare provider to guide you through the next steps. You may need to have a blood test also to provide the most accurate confirmation of pregnancy.

So, let me know in the comments: what made YOU take a home pregnancy test?!

An ear infection also known as otitis media is a condition that can cause pain in the ear, fever, and trouble hearing. Ear infections are common in children, especially between age 6 months and 3 years of age. Most ear infections occur after a child already has a cold.

This is because viruses or bacteria that are present during a cold can travel from the back of the throat into the middle ear causing the fluid in the ear to become infected and build up pressing on the eardrum and causing it to bulge which causes the symptoms.
 
👂 What are some of the symptoms of ear infection?
Ear infections can present in a variety of different ways. Sometimes its just a fever, or it can be pulling at the ear, being more fussy or less active than usual, having no appetite, and not eating as much, or have trouble hearing.
 
👂 How to prevent an ear infections?
These are somethings that have been shown to reduce the risk of ear infections:
* If possible, breastfeed your baby.
* Avoid bottle-feeding your baby when they are lying down.
* Transition your baby from a bottle to a cup by 1 year of age.
* Don’t smoke, and keep your child away from any second-hand smoke. Exposure to smoke can increase the risk of ear infections.
* If your child has had many ear infections, try reducing the use of pacifiers (soothers). Using a pacifier may increase the risk of repeated ear infections.
 
👂 Why are ear infections more common in children than adults?
Ear infections are more common in younger children because their eustachan tube, the tube that connects the middle ear to the back of the throat are shorter and more horizontal making it easier for bacteria or viruses to travel into the middle ear.

Being a new mom or a mom with small children can come with a little (or a lot!) of anxiety. You are responsible for a very vulnerable person and much of what you are going through will be new.  I have had experienced all of these thoughts in this video, and I am not alone ❤️

My friend and colleague Dr. Sarah Nunes, a psychologist had some great advice for managing anxiety in motherhood.

Understand that some anxiety is normal. Motherhood is a new endeavour with many unknowns. Alongside anxiety you may also experience mood changes (due to changing hormones and sleep deprivation), loneliness, and challenges with your partner.

Here are some things you can do to try and combat anxiety:

✳️Try ways to relax in your home:
* diaphragmatic breathing,
* meditation can help anxiety
* Do some self care – a hot relaxing bath, a massage or a short walk around your neighbourhood.
✳️Ask for help from family or friends, and find some time for yourself:
* Ask your partner to take the child out for an hour to yourself so you can de-stress.
* Ask an in-law (if possible) to come over to be with the child so you can have sometime to yourself.
* Find some down time when your child is at school or daycare to do some self care.
* Hire outside help if you can afford it.

✳️Try and pay attention to your extreme thoughts throughout the day
* Try to notice when you are getting carried away with a particular thought and ask yourself if there is evidence for the truthfulness of the thought.
* Notice the emotion that comes with the thought and label it (anger, sadness, guilt, etc).
* If you find yourself stuck in a negative thought, notice it without judgment and try gently redirecting it to a positive thought. We all have negative thoughts!

✳️Recognize when you are ruminating, or worrying excessively
* When worrying no longer generates new ideas this is called rumination.
* When this is happening, try to get busy doing something active or productive. Sitting and focusing on the rumination often makes it worse.

Please reach out to your healthcare provider if you are struggling.

Thoughts❤️👇

An ear infection also known as otitis media is a condition that can cause pain in the ear, fever, and trouble hearing. Ear infections are common in children, especially between age 6 months and 3 years of age. Most ear infections occur after a child already has a cold.

This is because viruses or bacteria that are present during a cold can travel from the back of the throat into the middle ear causing the fluid in the ear to become infected and build up pressing on the eardrum and causing it to bulge which causes the symptoms.
 
👂 What are some of the symptoms of ear infection?
Ear infections can present in a variety of different ways. Sometimes its just a fever, or it can be pulling at the ear, being more fussy or less active than usual, having no appetite, and not eating as much, or have trouble hearing.
 
👂 How to prevent an ear infections?
These are somethings that have been shown to reduce the risk of ear infections:
* If possible, breastfeed your baby.
* Avoid bottle-feeding your baby when they are lying down.
* Transition your baby from a bottle to a cup by 1 year of age.
* Don’t smoke, and keep your child away from any second-hand smoke. Exposure to smoke can increase the risk of ear infections.
* If your child has had many ear infections, try reducing the use of pacifiers (soothers). Using a pacifier may increase the risk of repeated ear infections.

👂 When do children need tubes in their ears?
If your child has frequent ear infections, or if they have trouble hearing because of ongoing fluid in the middle ear, they should see an Ear Nose and Throat (ENT) Surgeon to see if ear tubes are needed. Ear tubes (also called myringotomy tubes or tympanostomy tubes) are very small tubes that are surgically placed in your child’s eardrum by an ENT surgeon to help treat ear infections. The tube helps to keep air pressure normal on both sides of the ear drum and helps fluid drain from the middle ear.

🤒 What Is A Fever?
A fever is a sign that your body is fighting an infection.  A fever is not an illness, it means your body is responding to an illness. A fever usually goes away within 3 days. The following values below will help you determine if your child has a fever depending on where and how you take their temperature.

🌡 Normal Rectal Temp:
36.6 to 38°C or 97.9 to 100.4°F
🌡 Normal Armpit Temp:
36.5 to 37.5°C or 97.8 to 99.5°F
🌡 Normal Mouth Temp:
35.5 to 37.5°C or 95.9 to 99.5°F
🌡 Normal Ear Temp:
35.5 to 38°C or 96.4 to 100.4°F
🌡 Normal Forehead Temp:
35.7 to 37.5°C or 96.3 to 99.5°F
🤒 A fever is a temperature above the upper limit

A fever is a temperature above the upper limit of the temperature range for that location of the body.  How high the temperature is does not corelate with how sick your child is.  How your child is acting while having a fever is a better tell of how sick they are.

Babies younger than 3 months old should be assessed by a doctor if they have a fever. Older children can be treated at home so long as they get enough fluids and seem well otherwise.  Fever that lasts longer than 3 days should be discussed with a care provider.

Artificial sweeteners have been approved as safe for consumption by regulatory agencies such as the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and Health Canada. However, there is ongoing debate and research regarding their long-term effects on health. There are some situations where artificial sweeteners may be useful such as such for caloric management and for individuals with prediabetes or diabetes. Artificial sweeteners provide sweetness without adding significant calories to the diet and do not raise blood sugar levels, making them a suitable alternative for people with diabetes who need to control their blood glucose levels.

In general I recommend limiting the use of artificial sweaters as artificial sweeteners play no role in supporting hydration. Furthermore, artificial sweeteners are non-nutritive, meaning they offer no energy or nutritional value. While widely found in the food supply, the lack of research with human subjects is enough to cause pause with respect to safety. While many studies have shown that many sweeteners are safe, there’s still no clear consensus among the scientific community, and concerns persist.

The majority of rehydration drinks on the market contain artificial sweeteners. This was our inspiration for @pomme.md, a rehydration drink that contains essential electrolytes for hydration and sugars only from fresh pressed apple juice. Our rehydration drink is safe for all ages, pregnancy and breastfeeding!

Ear pain is a common problem that can occur in children during air travel as a result of pressure changes during flying. Pressure changes inside the ear during takeoff and landing can cause discomfort or even pain. Here are some tips we found helpful to prevent and treat ear pain for our children during flights:

💦 Drink fluids: Drinking fluids promotes swallowing which helps keep the eustachian tubes open and allows for ear pressure equalization.
🍬 Chewing gum or suck on hard candy: For older children chewing gum or sucking on candy can help equalize the pressure in the ear.
🍼Sucking: For baby’s, offer them a bottle or pacifier to suck on during takeoff and landing. Breastfeeding will also work well.
💊 Ibuprofen or acetaminophen: if your child has experienced ear pain previously, consider giving them acetaminophen or ibuprofen 30 minutes prior to takeoffs or landings. 
🧑‍⚕️Breathing exercises: older children can practice this exercise during takeoff and landing. Breath in slowly and then gently pitch the tip of the nose and gently exhale through the nose while keeping the mouth closed. Do this as many times as needed.

Have you tried these tips before?👇

These are some of the reasons peek-a-boo is so great for development

Social and emotional development: the baby will learn that the caregiver will come back after disappearing.

As our body’s largest organ - the skin always deserves gentle, loving care. This is especially so for our babies.

I often get new parents asking me about skincare for their little ones - there’s just so much available out there that it can be hard to know what to choose.

A few carefully considered choices can help support their skin’s moisture levels, as well as preventing and soothing dryness and irritation. But truthfully, your baby probably doesn’t need a whole bunch of products applied to their skin.

Many skincare products on the market - including some marketed for use on babies and young children - can contain harsh ingredients and chemicals that can be damaging to skin. For this reason, it’s really important to review the label and identify anything that could be harmful.

🚩 Red flags you need to be aware of:
➖ Fragrances - these can be really irritating to babies' sensitive skin. Look for fragrance-free or unscented options. Even “lightly scented” is a red flag.
➖ Harsh chemicals - such as sulfates, parabens and phthalates.
➖ Damaged packaging - if the packaging appears tampered with, don’t purchase or use it.
➖ Missing/unclear ingredients list - You can’t safely assess what you aren’t aware of.
➖ Missing expiry dates/lot numbers - these details are essential for tracking and ensuring the product’s freshness and quality.
➖ Bad reviews - others' experiences may give you clues as to the quality of the product.
➖ Artificial colorants - dyes and colorants can cause reactions.
➖ Food based ingredients - these may cause allergies in babies and young children. This is not always the case as some foods such as oats that contain Beta-glucan, a fiber are great for skin healing and hydration.

Tag a parent in the comments to help them recognise these red flags too 👇

Is there an association between heartburn and a hairy newborn?

Yes, there may be an association between heartburn and the amount of newborn hair!

A small study published in 2006 looked at 64 pregnant women ranked the severity of their degree of heartburn during pregnancy and the newborn baby’s hair volume at birth. The study found that there was an association between the heartburn severity and the amount of hair! If the pregnant mother had more severe heartburn, their baby was more likely to have lots of hair.

The theory is that the pregnancy hormones that stimulate fetal hair growth, also relax the esophageal sphincter, allowing stomach acid to back up into the esophagus and cause gastric reflux, aka heartburn.

However, it is important to note that this is a very small study (only 64 women) and the evidence collected was anecdotal and it’s possible that each woman had their own definition of severity of heartburn.

That being said, I found this study interesting! Have you heard this before?

Reference: Costigan et al. (2006) Pregnancy folklore revisited: the case of heartburn and hair. Birth. Dec;33(4):311-4.

All babies cry, and some more than others. Babies can be fussy for several reasons such as:​
·  Hunger or food sensitivities ​
·  Overstimulation ​
·  Wet diaper ​
·  Tired ​
·  Too hot or too cold ​

·  Colic ​
​
If your little one is fussy, try:​

·  Cuddle or safely swaddle your baby ​

·  Visit a lactation consultant ​

​
Talk to your doctor if you’re concerned about your baby’s fussiness or crying.

Tips for infant sleep👇

I think most parents have been frustrated at some point in time when it comes to baby sleep. There are many sleep-training methods out there. Choosing “the best” sleep-training method can be confusing. I know when I was sleep-training Madi – implementing the sleep-training techniques turned out to be more difficult than I anticipated.

*Sleep training is a personal choice, for us sleep training worked well, but there are many thriving families that did not sleep train.

Here are some tips before you start out:

✳️Do Your Research And See A Physician Before You Start Sleep-Training:
* Discuss with your child’s primary care provider to confirm that it is safe to sleep-train your child.  Your doctor will want to confirm that your child does not have any medical conditions that may prevent your child from being sleep trained.  
* Research how you plan to sleep-train your child.  There are many sleep-training methods out there, and choosing the best option for you is an individual choice. 
* Know that there is much information on the internet about the horrors of baby sleep training. To date there is no medical data that shows sleep-training causes attachment disorders, ADHD, depression, or anxiety.

✳️Plan Out The Best Time To Start Sleep-Training
* Make sure you implement a bedtime routine nightly.  
* Do not start baby sleep training before your child is 4 months old.  But do implement a good bedtime routine before you start sleep-training.  
* Know what the normal amount of sleep time your baby needs for their age.
* Have a plan and mutual goals with your partner about sleep-training. 

👶🏻Safety Of Your Infant Is Always A Priority
* Make sure they are comfortable and safe in their crib before leaving them alone in their room.

✳️All Sleep-Training Methods Require Periodic Checks On Your Baby.  
* There is no recommended “optimal” period of time between checks. 
* The amount of time between checks is determined by your personal tolerance for your child crying and your child’s temperament. 
* When in doubt, listen to your instincts. If you are worried about your child, attend to them as you need.  

Questions about infant sleep👇

Did you know that newborns are born without enough Vitamin K? 🤯

You might be thinking - “no big deal, they’ll receive this through diet, right?”

Well, not quite true. Breastmilk also contains very little Vitamin K - so babies who are exclusively breastfed do not obtain enough. Even formula fed babies will take time to build up their levels. But it’s generally around 4-6 months when babies start eating solids that Vitamin K levels generally improve.

The thing with Vitamin K is it’s actually crucial that our babies have enough right after birth. This is because our bodies need Vitamin K to stop bleeding and aid in the forming of clots.

As our tiny newborns are born with so little Vitamin K, they are at risk for Vitamin K Deficient Bleeding (VKDB) that can occur up to 6 months of age and cause serious health implications.

The good news is, VKDB can easily be prevented by administering a simple Vitamin K injection into the thigh of newborns within the first 6 hours of birth. I know it’s not nice to think of your baby receiving their first injection so soon - but this is offered for very good reason to keep your little one safe and is generally a quick, no-fuss procedure during which you can comfort, cuddle and feed your baby to soothe them.

Swipe to read more about how and why re recommend Vitamin K for all newborn babies.

I love the holiday season but it can be stressful with all of the events and expectations around the winter holidays. These are some tips I find helpful to reduce stress around the holidays

❄️ Understand that it is ok to say no to activities that are stressful. I love attending events, but also need downtime. Are tea bags better than warm compresses to treat eye infections?👇

Warm compresses can be good for our eyes! Warm compresses (placing a clean, warm, moist washcloth over your closed lids) can help treat eye conditions such as styes (red, painful lump at the edge of eyelids). But there is no evidence that using a “tea bag” is any better than a clean, warm washcloth (American Academy of Ophthalmology). On a personal note, I will say that I have used tea bags as they are affordable and fit over the eyes perfectly. However, it is important to ensure that the tea bags are clean and free from any additives or chemicals that could further irritate the eyes.

Ahhh… the dreaded daycare sickness 😷

If your little one is starting some form of daycare or early childhood education where they are around other children, then sickness might almost feel like a permanent fixture in your house for the next little while 😭

But, the good news is (yes, there’s good news) - these seemingly endless bouts of illness are setting your child up for a strong and healthy immune system as they grow 💪

So, why do our children get SO sick, SO often when they start daycare?

Well, when our children enter a daycare or early learning setting for the first time, their immune systems are generally exposed to more viruses than ever before. Pathogens are also able to spread quickly in these types of environments among a population of young children with still-developing immunity 🦠

But, how often is too often when it comes to sickness? Swipe to find out what you can expect.

Happy 7th birthday Madi! We love you very much. Your spunk, your thoughtfulness, your loving heart and your funny jokes! We love being your parents.

We remember when you were a baby like it was yesterday. The year you born was one of the busiest of your dad and my careers. Your dad was starting as chief resident and I was in my second year of practice and had so much to learn! Does turkey make you sleepy?

Turkey contains tryptophan. The tryptophan in turkey may play a small role in feeling sleepy after big holiday meals, but is not the sole reason! Tryptophan an essential amino acid that helps produce melatonin, the hormone that plays an important role in sleep and waking. Although there is tryptophan in turkey there isn’t enough tryptophan in a few servings of turkey to make you sleepy. It is likely the consumption of a large amount of carbohydrates and fats in holiday meals that leads to the sleepiness. Research shows that high-carbohydrate, high-fat meals lead to post-meal sleepiness, with peak fatigue happening an hour to an hour and a half after you finish eating. So don’t blame the turkey alone!

Did you know that honey should NEVER be given to babies under 12 months of age? 🍯❌

Honey is delicious and can be enjoyed in many ways, so it’s completely understandable that you’d be excited to share this with your little one as they embark on their solids journey. However, this is one of the foods that is NOT recommended to be offered to your baby until they are over one year old - and for good reason!

Honey can carry spores from a bacterium known as Clostridium botulinum. These spores are found in soil and can be brought back to the hive by bees.

The concern with honey is its potential to cause a serious but rare illness called botulism, specifically infantile botulism in babies. Babies under a year old lack the necessary good bacteria in their gut to offer protection from these spores and can become very unwell.

Symptoms can appear within 6 hours-30 days - so it’s important to be aware of these and seek urgent medical support should you notice these. Swipe to read more about what to look out for!

Remember, it’s best to avoid all forms of honey, including those present in other foods or baked goods, for babies under 12 months. This simple step can protect your little one from serious illness.

Did you know this? Make sure you tag a fellow parent in the comments to let them know too 👇

Why good posture postpartum matters👇

🧍‍♀️It reduces strain on the muscles, ligaments, and joints that may have been affected during pregnancy and delivery. This can help prevent pain and discomfort.
🧍‍♀️Good posture helps to engage and strengthen the core muscles, including the abdominal muscles, which may have been weakened during pregnancy. It aids in the recovery of diastasis recti (separation of the abdominal muscles) and promotes overall abdominal strength.

Tips for good posture postpartum

✳️Sit and stand tall: Imagine a string pulling you up from the top of your head, elongating your spine. Avoid slouching or hunching forward. Keep your shoulders even and keep your neutral spine (no flexing or arching to overemphasize the curve in your lower back). Your chin should also be parallel to the floor.

✳️Engage your core: Gently activate your deep abdominal muscles by drawing your belly button towards your spine. This helps to support your lower back and pelvic floor.

✳️Use supportive seating: Choose chairs and seats that provide good back support. When sitting down, keep your chin parallel to the floor; your shoulders, hips, and knees at even heights; and your knees and feet pointing straight ahead. When breastfeeding, use a chair with good back support or a nursing pillow to help support your baby’s weight and bring them closer to your breast. This can help you maintain a more upright position. And remember bring your baby to your breast, not your breast to your baby. Use pillows or cushions to raise your baby’s height if necessary.

✳️Avoid prolonged sitting or standing: Take regular breaks from sitting or standing for long periods. Alternate between sitting and standing, and incorporate gentle movement and stretching into your routine.

✳️Lift and carry with care: When lifting your baby or any heavy objects, bend your knees and use your leg muscles to lift, rather than straining your back. Hold objects close to your body and avoid twisting while lifting.

How is your posture?

Sleep problems during pregnancy are common, in fact, at least 50 percent of pregnant moms experience insomnia. There are many factors that lead to difficulty sleeping during pregnancy such as fluctuating hormone levels, general physical discomfort, nausea, increased urination and leg cramps to name a few. As time wears on, expectant mothers may also experience back pain and have trouble finding a comfortable position to accommodate the growing baby bump, especially when the baby starts to kick at night. There are also some sleep disorders that can arise during pregnancy such as obstructive sleep apnea, restless leg syndrome and gastroesophageal reflux disorder. 

Tips to improve sleep during pregnancy 👇
🤰 Starting with good sleep hygiene such as keeping a consistent wake up time, and a relaxing bedtime routine.
🤰 Find a comfortable sleep environment such as a cool, dark, quiet room and sleep position. I recommend the lying on your left side with your legs slightly curled and I liked having a pregnancy pillow to support my belly and to put in between my legs.
🤰 If you are experiencing heartburn or indigestion, try eating smaller and more frequent meals throughout the day and avoid heavy or spicy foods close to bedtime.
🤰 Getting exercise during the day can also help improve your sleep.

Please see your care provider if sleep disturbances persist or significantly impact your daily functioning.

MY TOP POSTS OF 2023❤️👇

1️⃣Should you use soaps to wash your vagina?

Avoid washing your vagina with harsh soaps or douching. There is good bacteria in our vagina called lactobacilli that keeps the vagina healthy. Washing or douching can hurt the good bacteria and increase your risk of infections such as bacterial vaginosis. 

A mild soap or cleanser can be used externally to clean the vulva. The vulva includes all of the external genitalia, including the labia majora, labia minora, glans clitoris and urethra.

2️⃣Are suspended baby jumpers like the Jolly Jumper safe?

The American Academy of Pediatrics states that “infants who spend too much time in confining equipment such as car seats, swings, bouncy seats, exersaucers, or strollers may experience delayed motor skill development.”
Health Canada also recommends that if a infant is using a suspended baby jumper that the infant is always supervised, that the manufacturer’s recommendations (age, weight, physical abilities of the baby, dimensions and strength of door frame) are followed, and that the jumper is adjusted to the babies height.

Both of my children loved jumping in their baby jumper and do so a few times a week. I will also admit that I find the jumper a bit of a sanity saver! When we use the jumper, I make sure I am close by and watching and limit the use to no more than 10 minutes at a time once per day.

3️⃣ Can you predict your baby’ gender by how you carry the pregnancy?

No! There is no evidence that the babies gender is related to the shape of the mother’s abdomen during pregnancy. 

Fetal sex can by determined ultrasound, prenatal blood test or amniocentesis.

Do these doctors @lifeofdrmom (family doctor) and @graememulholland.md (ENT surgeon) follow their own winter health tips👇

We both take vitamin D daily. While vitamin D is best known for its effect on calcium metabolism and for keeping our bones healthy, it appears to have benefits in preventing the common cold as well. One study found that vitamin D supplements can help prevent upper respiratory tract infections, especially in those who have a deficiency. In Canada, it is recommended that vitamin D supplements are taken year-round. Have a chat with your doctor to determine what dose would be right for you.

We don’t practice mindfulness daily but want to start incorporating it into our daily life. Mindfulness practices, such as meditation, can help reduce stress levels. Chronic stress can have detrimental effects on your physical health, including increased blood pressure, weakened immune system, and increased risk of heart disease. By practicing mindfulness, you can manage stress more effectively and promote overall well-being. Mindfulness encourages you to live in the present moment and appreciate the simple joys of life. It can increase feelings of gratitude and contentment.

Avoiding screen time before bed is important as screentime can negatively affect your sleep. Getting enough sleep is critical for our immune systems. Lack of sleep impairs our ability to fight off pathogens, and studies show that insufficient sleep in both the short and long term can increase your risk of getting sick. Please also keep in mind that children need more sleep than adults, so it’s important to ensure your kiddos are getting enough rest overnight (and across any naps if they’re little) so that they have enough energy to get through the day.

Drinking alcohol to stay warm can be dangerous👇

Alcohol may give the sensation of warmth, but it actually causes blood vessels to dilate, leading to increased heat loss from the body.

Lulled into a false sense of warmth, you may be tempted to shed a layer or two, accelerating heat loss in cold-weather. In addition, some may decide to walk home in the icy cold rather than getting a taxi or a lift which can put a person at risk of hypothermia.

❄️ Hypothermia is a medical emergency that occurs when your body loses heat faster than it can produce heat, causing a dangerously low body temperature.

It is a common myth that you can “sweat out” a hangover by exercising. In fact, exercising while hungover can actually be dangerous as alcohol dehydrates the body, and exercising can further deplete fluids and electrolytes. It’s best to focus on rehydrating and resting to recover from a hangover.

🍎 My favourite way to rehydrate is with @pomme.md. Pomme MD contains fresh pressed apple juice with essential electrolytes to aid in hydration. The use of real apple juice is key in hydration as apple juice contains a mixture of naturally occurring sugars including: fructose, glucose, and sucrose. In our intestines, there are multiple glucose transporters (eg. SGLT and GLUT-5 transporters) that allow our bodies to absorb sugar, electrolytes and water. Each of these transports use a different type of sugar such as glucose and fructose. The mixture of sugars in apples improves the hydration capacity by utilizing different transporters in our intestines. The multiple types of sugars in apples allow us to use multiple transporters to improve hydration capacity even more! 

It is important to note that artificial sweeteners in many of the rehydration beverages on the market do not aid in hydration!

Have you heard of the “sweat out” hangover myth?

Despite being a family doctor, I remember being very frazzled and stressed the first time my kids had a nosebleed. It took me a few minutes to gather my thoughts before I could even start moving!

🧑‍⚕️ To treat a nosebleed, you can follow these steps:

✅ Stay calm and get yourself and your child into a comfortable position
✅Pinch the nostrils: More than 90% of nose bleeds come from the front part of the nose called the nasal septum. Use your thumb and forefinger to pinch your nostrils (squishy part of the nose) together with firm but not painful pressure.  Squeeze your child’s nose for 10 minutes. Do not release the pressure until before the time is up. If you keep checking it will reduce the likelihood of the bleeding stopping.
✅ Tilt your child’s head forward. This will drain blood into the nose instead of into the back of the throat.
🧑‍⚕️ Please see your healthcare provider if you are experience frequent nosebleeds or if the bleeding persists.

Common causes of nosebleeds include:

👃🏾 Dry air: Dry or low-humidity environments can dry out the nasal membranes, making them more susceptible to bleeding. This is especially common during the winter months when indoor heating systems can reduce humidity.

👃🏾 Nose picking: Frequent or aggressive nose picking can damage the delicate blood vessels inside the nose, leading to bleeding.

👃🏾 Nasal trauma: Accidental injury to the nose, such as a blow to the face, can cause epistaxis.

👃🏾 Medications: Certain medications, especially those that thin the blood (anticoagulants) or have a drying effect on mucous membranes, may increase the risk of nosebleeds.

Breastmilk is beneficial to our babies and is the optimal form of nutrition for infants - as a Family Physician and mother myself, I am a strong advocate for breastfeeding and the benefits of breastmilk.

But… I’m also an advocate for families doing what is right for them. Sometimes, that means formula feeding whether exclusively, occasionally, or mixed feeding with breastmilk.
I breastfed and supplemented with formula.

Not that you ever need to justify your feeding decisions, but here are some perfectly OK reasons you might decide to formula feed your baby:

✅ Because you’ve struggled with your supply
✅ Because you’ve found breastfeeding uncomfortable
✅ Because formula is convenient
✅ Because you were physically unable to breastfeed
✅ Because you’re spending time away from your baby
✅ Because your baby has medical needs
✅ Because you’ve returned to work and can’t/don’t want to pump
✅ Because you want to
✅ Because it enables your partner/baby’s other caregivers to also feed baby
✅ Because this is working for your family
✅ Just because… you don’t need to give anyone a reason.

Know that however your feeding journey looks, there is a supportive space for you here in our community.

What is our favourite way to remove a loose baby tooth? 👶🏼🦷

Our family dentist @dentistallie recommends applying sustained pressure for ⏰ 10 seconds in each direction.

🦷 Push the tooth backwards with firm pressure and HOLD for a 10 count, and then forward for the same. This may pinch a little at first but will lessen as you hold it. This can be done multiple times per day!

🦷This is similar to how a dentist removes a tooth. A dentist will apply pressure and hold. This causes the bone around the tooth to expand, and allows the tooth to slowly loosen and come out.

Using a variation of this technique at home, can help your little one loosen their tooth and get it out all on their own 😃.

3️⃣Personal Development: University education helped me grow as a person. I was exposed to diverse perspectives and ideas which helped me develop critical thinking, problem-solving, and communication skills, which are essential for entrepreneurship.

As our @bydrmom company grows I realize that entrepreneurship is not solely dependent on formal education and have interacted with several successful entrepreneurs who have achieved success through self-learning, practical experience, and a strong entrepreneurial mindset.

The decision to attend university as an entrepreneur depends on individual circumstances and preferences, but I don’t agree with this post that education can negatively impact a child’s development. Education and learning can empower children to develop their interests and foster friendships.

What do you think?👇

Self-care tips for new moms👇

❤️Self care looks different for every mom but these are some things I have found helpful for my patients and myself.

🥗Nutrition: stay hydrated, you will need even more fluids if breastfeeding. Include protein in your diet, as it is important for postpartum recover and helps keep you full and satisfied. Include healthy fats like avocado, nuts and seeds. Include lots of fruits and veggies in your diet, in fact the Canada food guide recommends that half your plate be fruits and veggies!

🛌 Sleep: sleep is good for our physical and mental health. Adults ideally want to get 7-9 hours sleep. The newborn and baby phase can be an especially hard time to get sleep, but reach out to your partner or family and let them know if you’re feeling like you need some rest.

👯‍♀️Connect with others: you would think that by becoming a new mom you would never feel lonely since you have another person with you pretty much all of the time. For some, new parenthood can be some of the loneliest times. Consider joining a new mom group for a sense of community or support or reach out to friends and family to chat.

🧘Stay active: listen to your body, movement is good and do activities that feel good.

How did you find the first few months of motherhood?

Impetigo is a contagious bacterial skin infection. It most commonly occurs in children under the age of 5.  Because it is contagious, it can spread to other areas of the body or to other people easily.  
It can spread when someone touches an impetigo rash, or through items that have been in contact with infected skin.

✳️What Causes Impetigo?
Impetigo is caused by bacteria, usually Group A Streptococcus (strep) or Staphylococcus aureus (staph).  These are normal bacteria that normally live on the skin – but they can become problematic when they get into scrapes or even bug bites.  In some cases, impetigo can occur when the skin is irritated by a runny nose.  
It occurs the most during warm sunny months.  This is when kids are playing outside more and end up with more bumps and scrapes, and itchy insect bites.

✳️Signs And Symptoms 
Impetigo causes blister-like sores or red pimples. It usually appears around the mouth, nose, and skin not covered by clothes like arms or legs.  Eventually the blisters may start to ooze or crust-over with a yellowish scab.  
Parents need to watch out for signs of a more serious infection like fever, pain, swelling, or feeling weak.  This could be a sign that the infection is more serious than just a skin problem.

✳️Treatment Of Impetigo
Impetigo needs to be treated with antibiotics. In some cases, your doctor will use a topical cream or ointment to apply to the skin while in other cases, an oral antibiotic is required.  Call your doctor if you think your child has impetigo.

🛑If your child has impetigo:
* Keep the sores covered with a dressing until they are healed
* Wash your hands well with soap and water, especially after touching the skin
* Do not share facecloths or towels between family members
* Make sure your child finishes the course of antibiotics prescribed
* Keep your child’s nails trimmed so they don’t scratch their skin 

Thoughts/?👇

Hearing your child say their first words, and start to verbally communicate with you in a way you can understand is incredibly exciting - and a huge milestone in their development.

We usually expect young toddlers to start using a few words between 12-15 months. These are typically very basic such as ‘Mama’ ‘Cat’ ‘Dog ‘Ball’ etc.

However, it’s very important to know that language development in children occurs in stages, over time. They don’t suddenly go from baby babbling to full-blown sentences overnight. Some kids may seem to pick up language faster than others, and this is usually OK and expected - it can be very normal for children’s development to occur at different stages and in different ways.

Many parents do go through a period of worrying about their little one’s sleep and often this comes down to comparison with other children. If this is you, you are not alone. I experienced this myself when my daughter was little and we met another child the same age at the park who was speaking in full sentences at 16 months. It sent me on a bit of a spin before I realized my girl was exactly where she needed to be, and I was over-reacting.

But, when should you actually be worried? Let’s talk about it and identify some of the red flags together - SWIPE to read more!

It’s a myth! 👇

Some people believe that a high and pointed all-belly bump indicates that you’re carrying a boy, whereas a wide, low, weight-goes-everywhere bump suggests a girl. The truth is that that the shape of the belly has no relation to the baby’s gender. The shape of a  pregnancy bump is determined by factors like the mother’s body shape, muscle tone, and the position of the baby.

During pregnancy, some women experience a big spike in libido, while others are completely and utterly turned off by the mere suggestion of physical intimacy. Did you know that balance is a predictor of longevity?

A study found that inability to stand unsupported on one leg for 10 seconds was associated with an 84% increased risk of death.

We know that balance quickly diminishes after the mid-50s increasing the risk for falls and other adverse health outcomes. A study published in the BMJ in 2022 found that the inability to stand unsupported on one leg for 10 seconds was associated with an 84% heightened risk of death from any cause within the next decade.

The study included 1702 participants aged 51–75 (average of 61). Participants were asked to stand on one leg for 10 seconds without any additional support. Up to three attempts on either foot were permitted.

In all, around 1 in 5 (20.5%; 348) participants failed to pass the test. The inability to stand on one leg increased with age.

Have you tested your balance?
